countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, a role, or an AWS service in Amazon S3. You can use information collected by CloudTrail to determine the following:

  • The request that was made to Amazon S3
  • The IP address from which the request was made
  • Who made the request
  • When the request was made
  • Additional details about the request

For example, you can identify CloudTrail entries for PUT actions that affect data access, in particular PutBucketAcl, PutObjectAcl, PutBucketPolicy, and PutBucketWebsite.

When you set up your AWS account, CloudTrail is enabled by default. You can view recent events in the CloudTrail console. To create an ongoing record of activity and events for your Amazon S3 buckets, you can create a trail in the CloudTrail console. For more information, see Logging data events in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

When you create a trail, you can configure CloudTrail to log data events. Data events are records of resource operations performed on or within a resource. In Amazon S3, data events record object-level API activity for individual buckets. CloudTrail supports a subset of Amazon S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject. For more information about how CloudTrail works with Amazon S3, see Logging Amazon S3 API calls using AWS CloudTrail. In the Amazon S3 console, you can also configure your S3 buckets to Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects.

AWS Config provides a managed rule (cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled) that you can use to confirm that at least one CloudTrail trail is logging data events for your S3 buckets. For more information, see cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for applications and AWS services that require Amazon S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
In order for applications running on Amazon EC2 or other AWS services to access Amazon S3 resources, they must include valid AWS credentials in their AWS API requests. We recommend not storing AWS credentials directly in the application or Amazon EC2 instance. These are long-term credentials that are not automatically rotated and could have a significant business impact if they are compromised.

Instead, use an IAM role to manage temporary credentials for applications or services that need to access Amazon S3. When you use a role, you don't have to distribute long-term credentials (such as a username and password or access keys) to an Amazon EC2 instance or AWS service, such as AWS Lambda. The role supplies temporary permissions that applications can use when they make calls to other AWS resources.

For more information, see the following topics in the IAM User Guide:

  • IAM Roles
  • Common Scenarios for Roles: Users, Applications, and Services

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Storage Lens
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Storage Lens is a cloud-storage analytics feature that you can use to gain organization-wide visibility into object-storage usage and activity. S3 Storage Lens also analyzes metrics to deliver contextual recommendations that you can use to optimize storage costs and apply best practices for protecting your data.

With S3 Storage Lens, you can use metrics to generate summary insights, such as finding out how much storage you have across your entire organization or which are the fastest-growing buckets and prefixes. You can also use S3 Storage Lens metrics to identify cost-optimization opportunities, implement data-protection and access-management best practices, and improve the performance of application workloads.

For example, you can identify buckets that don't have S3 Lifecycle rules to abort incomplete multipart uploads that are more than 7 days old. You can also identify buckets that aren't following data-protection best practices, such as using S3 Replication or S3 Versioning. For more information, see Understanding Amazon S3 Storage Lens.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized extraction of sensitive data from S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in Amazon S3 buckets may be extracted without proper oversight due to inadequate monitoring and insufficient access controls. This can lead to unauthorized data access, leaks, and breaches, compromising the integrity and confidentiality of the data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak access controls, lack of encryption, and insufficient logging and monitoring mechanisms, allowing undetected data exfiltration.

Impacts

Impacts include severe data breaches, loss of intellectual property, financial losses, legal consequences due to non-compliance with data protection regulations, and damage to an organization's reputation and customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An insider with access to an S3 bucket containing sensitive customer information downloads the data without being detected due to a lack of proper monitoring and oversight.
  2. An external attacker compromises an employee's AWS credentials and uses them to extract sensitive data from an S3 bucket, leading to a significant data breach and regulatory fines.
  3. Sensitive financial data stored in an S3 bucket is exfiltrated by an attacker exploiting overly permissive access controls, resulting in the exposure of confidential business information and competitive disadvantage.
  4. A lack of proper logging and alerting mechanisms allows an attacker to continuously extract small amounts of sensitive data over an extended period, going unnoticed until the breach is discovered during an audit.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The lack of adequate monitoring of Amazon S3 buckets can result in undetected data breaches or data loss. Without proper logging, alerting, and monitoring mechanisms, unauthorized access or malicious activities can go unnoticed, leading to severe security and compliance issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or non-existent monitoring systems, allowing attackers to access, modify, or extract data without detection.

Impacts

Impacts include significant data breaches, loss of sensitive and critical data, non-compliance with regulatory requirements, financial losses, and damage to the organization's reputation and customer trust. The inability to detect and respond to security incidents in a timely manner exacerbates these risks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to an S3 bucket and exfiltrates sensitive data over time. Due to inadequate monitoring, the breach remains undetected until the data is leaked or sold on the dark web, resulting in a major security incident.
  2. An insider with malicious intent deletes critical business data from an S3 bucket. Without proper monitoring and alerting mechanisms, the data loss is not identified until business operations are disrupted, causing significant financial and operational impacts.
  3. During a routine compliance audit, an organization discovers that an S3 bucket containing regulated data has been accessed by unauthorized users multiple times over the past year, leading to substantial fines and legal consequences.
  4. A lack of detailed logging and alerting allows an attacker to use compromised credentials to make unauthorized changes to an S3 bucket policy, granting themselves ongoing access and leading to a prolonged data breach that goes unnoticed for months.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure S3 bucket configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Amazon S3 buckets that are not properly secured may be accessible by unauthorized users. This can result from misconfigured permissions, lack of encryption, and absence of stringent access controls, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized data access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated bots scanning for misconfigured buckets. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or incorrect bucket policies, overly permissive access controls, and publicly accessible buckets without proper security measures.

Impacts

Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, loss of intellectual property, compliance violations, financial penalties, and damage to the organization's reputation. Misconfigured buckets can also lead to data manipulation or deletion, further compromising data integrity and availability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An S3 bucket containing confidential customer data is mistakenly configured with public read access, allowing anyone on the internet to access and download sensitive information, resulting in a significant data breach.
  2. During a routine security scan, it is discovered that several S3 buckets are accessible to unauthorized internal users due to misconfigured IAM policies, leading to unauthorized access and potential data leaks.
  3. An external attacker uses automated tools to identify and access an S3 bucket that has been inadvertently left publicly accessible. The attacker exfiltrates proprietary business information, causing financial and reputational damage to the company.
  4. A developer unintentionally grants write permissions to all authenticated AWS users on an S3 bucket, allowing unauthorized users to upload malicious content or delete critical data, leading to operational disruptions and potential legal issues.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

component.name: AWS Data Lake
component.desc: Data lake on AWS.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Enable detailed logging
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance visibility into data access and modifications within AWS Lake Formation, it is essential to enable detailed logging of Lake Formation activities. These logs help monitor and audit various actions performed in the data lake, ensuring that any unauthorized access or changes are promptly identified and addressed.

Here's a step-by-step guide to implement detailed logging for Lake Formation:

  1. Enable AWS CloudTrail: Ensure that AWS CloudTrail is enabled in your account. CloudTrail tracks API calls made to AWS Lake Formation, recording information such as the identity of the caller, the time of the call, and the details of the API request. For instructions on enabling CloudTrail, refer to the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.
  2. Configure AWS Config Rules: Set up AWS Config rules to monitor compliance with best security practices in AWS Lake Formation. AWS Config can continuously assess whether your resources and their configurations comply with the configurations that you specify. See more about AWS Config in the AWS Config Developer Guide.
  3. Define Logging and Monitoring Policies: Establish policies for what specific activities need to be logged and monitored. This includes defining which Lake Formation actions and resources should trigger logging events. For a comprehensive list of Lake Formation actions that can be logged, refer to the Lake Formation Logging and Monitoring guide.
  4. Store and Analyze Logs: Utilize Amazon S3 to store the logs generated by CloudTrail and Amazon CloudWatch Logs for real-time monitoring and analysis. You can set up CloudWatch Alarms for automated notifications based on log queries and metrics.
  5. Review and Audit Logs Regularly: Regularly review the logs to identify any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts. Periodic auditing ensures that your security policies and controls are effective. Detailed information on how to audit AWS Lake Formation activities can be found in the AWS Lake Formation Security Guidelines.

Implementing these measures ensures that you have robust logging and monitoring in place for AWS Lake Formation, enhancing your ability to maintain data security and integrity. For further details on security best practices for AWS Lake Formation, refer to the AWS Documentation on Security in Lake Formation.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that all data stored in AWS Lake Formation is encrypted at rest using AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS), follow the security best practices as outlined in the AWS Lake Formation documentation.

Step-by-Step Guidance:

  1. Create a Key in AWS KMS: First, you need to create a Customer Managed Key (CMK) in AWS KMS. Navigate to the AWS KMS console, choose Customer managed keys, and then click Create key. Follow the wizard and configure the key policy to ensure appropriate access permissions are set.

    For more details, refer to the AWS KMS Documentation.

  2. Configure Data Lake Settings: In the AWS Lake Formation console, go to the Data Lake Settings. Under the Encryption section, select Default encryption for data stores. Choose Enable encryption and select the Customer Managed Key (CMK) created in AWS KMS.

    Refer to the Encryption at Rest documentation for additional details.

  3. Encrypt Data: When you create or register new data locations, ensure that the encryption settings are properly configured to use the specified KMS key. AWS Lake Formation will automatically encrypt the data at rest using the provided KMS key.

  4. Verify Encryption Status: Periodically verify the encryption status of your data. You can do this by accessing the AWS Lake Formation console and reviewing the properties of your data lake locations to ensure that encryption is enabled and using the correct KMS key.

References:

  • AWS Lake Formation - Encryption at Rest
  • AWS KMS - Creating Keys
  • AWS Lake Formation - Data Encryption

countermeasure.name: Use SourceArn and SourceAccount to restrict AWS Lake Formation permissions
countermeasure.desc:
To mitigate the risk of cross-service confused deputy attacks in AWS Lake Formation, it is crucial to restrict permissions to specific trusted accounts and resources. This can be accomplished by leveraging the SourceArn and SourceAccount global condition context keys. By using these keys, you can ensure that AWS Lake Formation interactions are only permitted from specified sources, thereby reducing the risk of unauthorized access. Follow these steps to implement this control:

  1. Identify the ARNs of the resources and AWS accounts that require access to AWS Lake Formation. Document these ARNs for use in your policy.
  2. Navigate to the AWS IAM console and access the policy editor to create or modify the IAM policies related to AWS Lake Formation.
  3. Within the policy, add conditions using the SourceArn and SourceAccount condition keys to restrict access. For example: 
    
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": {
    "Effect": "Allow",
    "Action": ["lakeformation:*"],
    "Resource": "*",
    "Condition": {
      "StringEquals": {
        "aws:SourceAccount": "123456789012"
      },
      "StringLike": {
        "aws:SourceArn": "arn:aws:s3:::example-bucket/*"
      }
    }
  }
}
  4. Review the policy to ensure it correctly covers all required entities and does not inadvertently grant broader access.
  5. Apply the policy to the relevant IAM roles or users who will be interacting with AWS Lake Formation.
  6. Test the policy to verify that permissions work as expected and that access is denied when attempted from unauthorized accounts or resources.

For further details on preventing cross-service confused deputy attacks and using global condition context keys, refer to the AWS Lake Formation documentation on Cross-Service Confused Deputy Prevention.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Cross-service confused deputy
threat.desc:
General threat description
In a cross-service confused deputy attack, an attacker uses a less-privileged service to perform actions on behalf of a highly privileged service, leading to potential unauthorized access and actions.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers exploit weaknesses in inter-service trust and permission models to manipulate less-privileged services into making requests on behalf of highly privileged services.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive data, execution of unauthorized actions, and potential compromise of the entire AWS Lake Formation environment.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker compromises a read-only data processing service and manipulates it to escalate privileges and gain access to the data catalog, allowing them to read or alter sensitive information in the data lake.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure data storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing sensitive data without proper encryption measures can result in data being exposed to unauthorized users. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit misconfigured AWS Lake Formation settings or vulnerabilities to access unencrypted sensitive data, or insiders with unauthorized access may misuse their privileges. 
Impacts
Potential loss of confidential information, financial loss, reputational damage, and regulatory penalties. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an AWS Lake Formation due to improperly set permissions and accesses unencrypted sensitive data, resulting in a data breach. Alternatively, an insider with elevated privileges extracts and misuses unencrypted sensitive information for personal gain.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring of access and activity
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of adequate monitoring and auditing mechanisms can significantly weaken the ability to detect unauthorized access or suspicious activities within AWS Lake Formation environments.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, malicious insiders, or external attackers who exploit the absence of real-time monitoring and auditing to gain or maintain access to sensitive data undetected.
Impacts
Potential unauthorized data access, data leakage, data modification, and compliance violations; delayed incident response and extended recovery times.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to Lake Formation resources and exfiltrates sensitive data over time. Due to the lack of monitoring and auditing, the unauthorized access goes unnoticed until the damage is already done. Another scenario involves an insider who continually accesses restricted datasets without any detection, potentially leaking confidential information to external parties.

component.name: AWS DataSync
component.desc: AWS DataSync for data transfer.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

countermeasure.name: Ensure that data at rest is encrypted using AWS managed keys or customer-managed keys
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that data at rest is encrypted in AWS DataSync, you must use either AWS managed keys (SSE-S3 or SSE-KMS) or customer-managed keys. This is crucial for protecting sensitive data from unauthorized access. Follow the steps below to implement this control:

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console.
  2. Navigate to the DataSync service.
  3. When setting up a task, under the "Data transfer configuration" section, ensure that the "Data at rest encryption" option is enabled.
  4. Select the desired encryption type:
    • AWS Managed Keys (AWS KMS): Choose 'AWS managed keys' and proceed. AWS will automatically manage the encryption keys.
    • Customer-Managed Keys (CMK): Choose 'Customer managed keys' and select a KMS key that you have created previously.
  5. Complete the task setup and start the data transfer.

Refer to the official AWS documentation for more details: AWS DataSync Security - Data Encryption.

reference.name: CWE-326: CWE-326

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Use resource-based policies with conditions
countermeasure.desc:
When configuring resource-based policies, such as S3 bucket policies, for AWS DataSync, it is essential to use condition keys to ensure that only DataSync tasks from your specific AWS account can access these resources. This can be achieved by utilizing the 'aws:SourceAccount' and 'aws:SourceArn' condition keys in your policy statements. This practice effectively mitigates the risk of the confused deputy problem.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify the Resource: Determine the AWS resources that your DataSync tasks will interact with, such as S3 buckets.
  2. Edit the Resource Policy: Navigate to the policy configuration for the identified resource. For S3 buckets, this can be done via the S3 management console or AWS CLI.
  3. Add Conditions: Modify the resource policy to include the 'aws:SourceAccount' and 'aws:SourceArn' conditions. This ensures that only requests coming from DataSync tasks in your AWS account will be allowed. Below is an example policy for an S3 bucket:{    "Version": "2012-10-17",    "Statement": [        {            "Effect": "Allow",            "Principal": {                "Service": "datasync.amazonaws.com"            },            "Action": "s3:*",            "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::YourBucketName/*",            "Condition": {                "StringEquals": {                    "aws:SourceAccount": "YOUR_ACCOUNT_ID"                },                "ArnLike": {                    "aws:SourceArn": "arn:aws:datasync:REGION:YOUR_ACCOUNT_ID:task/TASK_ID"                }            }        }    ] }        
  4. Test the Policy: Validate the policy by running a DataSync task and ensuring that it can access the resource as intended. Make sure no unauthorized access is allowed.

For more detailed information on confused deputy prevention and cross-service access policies, refer to the AWS DataSync Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use security groups and network access control lists (ACLs) to restrict access to your DataSync endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of AWS DataSync, it is essential to use Security Groups and Network Access Control Lists (ACLs) to restrict access to your DataSync endpoints, ensuring only trusted IP ranges can communicate with your DataSync agents.

Steps to Implement

  1. Identify the VPC in which your DataSync agents are running.
  2. Security Groups Configuration:
    1. In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the EC2 service and select Security Groups.
    2. Create a new security group or select an existing one that is associated with your DataSync agents.
    3. Add inbound rules to the security group to allow traffic only from trusted IP ranges. Define the protocol and port ranges that you wish to permit.
    4. Similarly, add outbound rules to ensure that traffic from your DataSync agents can only communicate with trusted IP ranges.
  3. Network ACLs Configuration:
    1. Navigate to the VPC service and select Network ACLs.
    2. Create a new Network ACL or select an existing one associated with the subnet hosting your DataSync agents.
    3. Edit the inbound rules to allow traffic only from the trusted IP ranges and ports relevant for DataSync communication.
    4. Edit the outbound rules to similarly restrict traffic only to trusted IP ranges.

References:

  • AWS DataSync Security in Your VPC

countermeasure.name: Use the built-in data integrity verification features of AWS DataSync
countermeasure.desc:
AWS DataSync includes built-in data integrity verification features to ensure that data is transferred correctly and reliably. Implementing these features can help safeguard the integrity of your data during transfer. Heres how you can enable and use these features:

  1. DataSync automatically performs data integrity checks during data transfer by calculating and comparing checksums on the source and destination files. This ensures that any corrupted files can be detected and retried.
  2. To enable data integrity verification, you simply need to use the DataSync service as provided. These integrity checks are automatically part of the transfer process, ensuring that any inconsistencies are identified and logged.
  3. Additionally, ensure that you consistently monitor DataSync logs for any integrity verification errors and take necessary actions if inconsistencies are detected.

For more detailed information on data integrity verification, please refer to the official AWS DataSync security documentation: AWS DataSync Security Data Integrity.

countermeasure.name: Use VPC endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS DataSync transfers, you should utilize VPC endpoints. VPC endpoints enable private connectivity between your VPC and AWS DataSync without requiring an internet gateway, NAT device, VPN connection, or AWS Direct Connect connection. This reduces the exposure to potential network-based attacks.

Follow these steps to implement VPC endpoints for DataSync:

  1. Identify the appropriate VPC endpoint service for DataSync within your AWS region.
  2. Create a VPC endpoint in your AWS Management Console. Ensure it is associated with the correct VPC and appropriate subnet(s).
  3. Update the security group rules to restrict access to DataSync agents and tasks to trusted sources only.
  4. Modify your DataSync Task settings to use the VPC endpoint for communications. This is done by specifying the VPC endpoint ID in the task's network settings.
  5. Test the configuration by running a DataSync task to ensure it properly utilizes the VPC endpoint without any issues.

For detailed steps and additional security considerations, consult the official AWS DataSync security documentation at https://docs.aws.amazon.com/datasync/latest/userguide/security-vpc-endpoints.html.

countermeasure.name: Validate the role session name
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS DataSync service when using temporary security credentials provided by an IAM role, ensure that the role session name conforms to your expected structure. This assists in mitigating the risk of role assumption by unauthorized users. Follow these steps:

  1. Define a naming convention for role session names that includes identifiable patterns such as prefixes, suffixes, or specific formats that are unique to your organization.
  2. Implement checks in your automation scripts or AWS Lambda functions to validate that the role session name adheres to the defined structure before granting access.
  3. Use AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies to enforce session name requirements by specifying conditions in trust policies.

For detailed guidelines and best practices, refer to the AWS Security Documentation: AWS DataSync Security. Additional recommendations on session name validation can be found in the Preventing the Confused Deputy Problem section of the AWS DataSync User Guide.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Confused deputy problem
threat.desc:
General threat description
An attacker can exploit the confused deputy problem to trick the AWS DataSync service into performing unintended actions on the attacker's behalf, leading to unauthorized data access or manipulation.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit vulnerabilities in the AWS DataSync service, typically by crafting malicious requests or exploiting misconfigured permissions to deceitfully leverage higher-privileged roles or services.
Impacts
This can result in unauthorized data access, data manipulation, or service disruption, potentially breaching confidentiality, integrity, and availability of sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker might create a request that appears to come from a trustworthy service but actually directs DataSync to transfer sensitive data to an unauthorized location or delete critical data. Another scenario could involve manipulating role-based access controls to perform unauthorized operations on data stored within AWS services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1528 - Steal Application Access Token

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unsecured data at rest
threat.desc:
General threat description
Data exposure due to improper security measures
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cyber criminals or unauthorized personnel exploiting misconfigurations, insufficient access controls, or vulnerabilities in the data storage setup
Impacts
Compromised sensitive information, financial losses, legal challenges, and damage to brand reputation
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to AWS Data-Sync and retrieves sensitive data due to misconfigured bucket policies, or a former employee accesses long-term stored data without proper revocation of credentials.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Data integrity issues during transfer
threat.desc:
General threat description
Data can be corrupted or lost during the transfer process, resulting in incomplete or incorrect data states at the destination.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
This threat can be introduced by network failures, hardware malfunctions, software bugs, or malicious activities such as man-in-the-middle attacks.
Impacts
The primary impact is the integrity and accuracy of the data being transferred. This can lead to operational disruptions, loss of critical information, and potential financial losses or reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker intercepts the data transfer and injects malicious data, causing corruption on the destination system.
2. A network interruption occurs during a critical data transfer, causing data packets to be lost and leading to incomplete data replication.
3. A software bug in the Data-Sync tool results in erroneous data being written to the destination, thereby compromising the data integrity.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to DataSync endpoints
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers gaining unauthorized access to DataSync endpoints can lead to data breaches or data loss. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
External attackers or malicious insiders exploiting weak authentication mechanisms, misconfigurations, or vulnerabilities in the network to access DataSync endpoints. 
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive data, data breaches, potential financial losses, regulatory penalties, and reputational damage. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses stolen credentials to log into a DataSync endpoint, exfiltrating sensitive data to an external server. Another scenario could involve a misconfigured endpoint exposed to the internet, allowing attackers to gain unauthorized access and delete critical business data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

component.name: AWS DataSync Agents
component.desc: AWS DataSync agents in the Local DC.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

countermeasure.name: Ensure that data at rest is encrypted using AWS managed keys or customer-managed keys
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that data at rest is encrypted in AWS DataSync, you must use either AWS managed keys (SSE-S3 or SSE-KMS) or customer-managed keys. This is crucial for protecting sensitive data from unauthorized access. Follow the steps below to implement this control:

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console.
  2. Navigate to the DataSync service.
  3. When setting up a task, under the "Data transfer configuration" section, ensure that the "Data at rest encryption" option is enabled.
  4. Select the desired encryption type:
    • AWS Managed Keys (AWS KMS): Choose 'AWS managed keys' and proceed. AWS will automatically manage the encryption keys.
    • Customer-Managed Keys (CMK): Choose 'Customer managed keys' and select a KMS key that you have created previously.
  5. Complete the task setup and start the data transfer.

Refer to the official AWS documentation for more details: AWS DataSync Security - Data Encryption.

reference.name: CWE-326: CWE-326

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Use resource-based policies with conditions
countermeasure.desc:
When configuring resource-based policies, such as S3 bucket policies, for AWS DataSync, it is essential to use condition keys to ensure that only DataSync tasks from your specific AWS account can access these resources. This can be achieved by utilizing the 'aws:SourceAccount' and 'aws:SourceArn' condition keys in your policy statements. This practice effectively mitigates the risk of the confused deputy problem.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify the Resource: Determine the AWS resources that your DataSync tasks will interact with, such as S3 buckets.
  2. Edit the Resource Policy: Navigate to the policy configuration for the identified resource. For S3 buckets, this can be done via the S3 management console or AWS CLI.
  3. Add Conditions: Modify the resource policy to include the 'aws:SourceAccount' and 'aws:SourceArn' conditions. This ensures that only requests coming from DataSync tasks in your AWS account will be allowed. Below is an example policy for an S3 bucket:{    "Version": "2012-10-17",    "Statement": [        {            "Effect": "Allow",            "Principal": {                "Service": "datasync.amazonaws.com"            },            "Action": "s3:*",            "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::YourBucketName/*",            "Condition": {                "StringEquals": {                    "aws:SourceAccount": "YOUR_ACCOUNT_ID"                },                "ArnLike": {                    "aws:SourceArn": "arn:aws:datasync:REGION:YOUR_ACCOUNT_ID:task/TASK_ID"                }            }        }    ] }        
  4. Test the Policy: Validate the policy by running a DataSync task and ensuring that it can access the resource as intended. Make sure no unauthorized access is allowed.

For more detailed information on confused deputy prevention and cross-service access policies, refer to the AWS DataSync Security Documentation.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

countermeasure.name: Configure AWS DMS to use secure endpoints for encrypted data transfer
countermeasure.desc:
To protect data during AWS DMS migrations, configure secure endpoints to ensure encrypted communication between replication instances and databases:

Enable SSL/TLS for Endpoints:

  • When setting up source and target endpoints in AWS DMS, enable SSL/TLS encryption. This ensures that data transferred between databases and replication instances is encrypted in transit.

Use Verified Certificates:

  • Ensure SSL/TLS certificates used for encryption are signed by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA) and are up-to-date. This prevents man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks and ensures the authenticity of the endpoints.

Enforce Encryption Policies:

  • Apply AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies to enforce encryption requirements for all DMS tasks. This restricts the creation of non-secure endpoints.

Monitor Endpoint Security:

  • Regularly audit endpoint configurations using AWS Config or AWS Security Hub to ensure compliance with encryption best practices and detect any deviations from secure settings.

reference.name: Security in AWS Database Migration Service

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Enable detailed logging and monitoring for DMS tasks
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS DMS operations, enable detailed logging and monitoring:

Enable CloudWatch Logs:

  • Configure CloudWatch Logs for DMS tasks to capture execution metrics and errors.
  • Set CloudWatch Alarms for abnormal task behavior, such as failures or unusual data changes.

Use CloudTrail for Auditing:

  • Ensure CloudTrail is enabled to log all API calls related to AWS DMS for auditing and analysis.
  • Store CloudTrail logs in a secure S3 bucket for review and compliance.

Set Up Real-Time Alerts:

  • Use CloudWatch Events to trigger alerts or automated responses to suspicious activities.
  • Integrate with AWS Security Hub or GuardDuty to enhance detection of potential threats.

reference.name: Logging task settings

countermeasure.name: Use AWS DMS built-in data validation for migration accuracy
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure data consistency and prevent corruption during AWS DMS migrations, enable the service's built-in data validation feature:

Enable Data Validation:

  • In the AWS DMS console, activate the data validation option when configuring a migration task. This feature checks that the data in the source and target databases matches after migration, ensuring consistency.

Configure Validation Rules:

  • Set up validation rules to verify row counts, checksums, and data types for tables being migrated. Adjust the rules based on the criticality and sensitivity of the data to catch discrepancies early.

Monitor Validation Results:

  • Regularly monitor validation reports and logs to identify and resolve any mismatches or data integrity issues promptly.
  • Set up CloudWatch Alarms to receive notifications if validation failures occur, allowing quick corrective actions.

reference.name: AWS DMS data validation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure communication endpoints
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Insecure communication endpoints in AWS DMS refer to vulnerabilities where data transmitted between source and target databases, or between AWS DMS instances, is not adequately encrypted. This can lead to interception, unauthorized access, or alteration of data, especially during migrations involving sensitive information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, state actors.
  • Vectors: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing on unencrypted networks, exploiting weak or misconfigured encryption settings, DNS spoofing.

Impacts:

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized data access.
  • Integrity: Data tampering or corruption.
  • Availability: Disruption of migration processes.
  • Compliance: Breaches of GDPR, HIPAA, CCPA, leading to fines and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Unencrypted Data Transfer: During migration, data is transmitted without SSL, allowing attackers to intercept and extract sensitive information.
  • Man-in-the-Middle Attack: An attacker intercepts communication between AWS DMS and databases, accessing and potentially modifying data.
  • Weak Encryption Exploit: An attacker forces a downgrade to a vulnerable encryption standard, decrypting sensitive traffic during migration.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Lack of task monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Lack of Task Monitoring" in AWS DMS refers to the inadequate or absent monitoring of migration tasks, which can lead to undetected errors, unauthorized modifications, or malicious activities during data migration. Without proper oversight, tasks may fail, become corrupted, or be manipulated without triggering alerts or corrective actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, cybercriminals, negligent administrators.
  • Vectors: Unmonitored or poorly configured DMS tasks, unauthorized changes to migration settings, exploitation of gaps in task management, or use of compromised credentials.

Impacts:

  • Data Loss/Corruption: Unnoticed task failures or unauthorized changes can result in incomplete or corrupted data migrations.
  • Operational Disruption: Prolonged or unnoticed migration issues can delay critical operations.
  • Security Risks: Unmonitored tasks may allow unnoticed data theft or manipulation by malicious actors.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Unnoticed Task Failure: A data migration task fails midway due to a network issue, but without proper monitoring, the failure goes unnoticed, resulting in incomplete data transfer.
  • Unauthorized Modifications: A malicious insider alters the migration task settings to divert sensitive data to an unauthorized location, and due to lack of monitoring, the change remains undetected.
  • Data Corruption Overlooked: During a large-scale migration, data gets corrupted due to configuration errors, but without real-time monitoring or alerts, the issue is only discovered after the migration is complete, requiring a costly rollback and redo.

threat.name: Data integrity compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Data Integrity Compromise" in AWS DMS refers to the risk of data being altered, corrupted, or manipulated during migration processes. This can occur due to software bugs, configuration errors, or malicious attacks, leading to the loss of data accuracy and reliability, which is crucial for decision-making and operational processes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, accidental errors by administrators.
  • Vectors: Exploiting vulnerabilities in AWS DMS configurations, injecting malicious data during migration, tampering with data in transit, or manipulating data storage settings.

Impacts:

  • Data Accuracy: Inaccurate or incomplete data can lead to faulty analytics and decision-making.
  • Operational Disruption: Corrupted data can disrupt applications and processes dependent on accurate data.
  • Financial Loss: Incorrect data can lead to financial errors, regulatory fines, and loss of customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Malicious Data Injection: An attacker gains access to the DMS instance and injects false records into the database during migration, causing significant discrepancies in financial reporting.
  • Configuration Error: An administrator accidentally configures the migration task to exclude critical data fields, resulting in a partial and inaccurate data set being transferred.
  • Data Tampering in Transit: During migration, data packets are intercepted and modified by a man-in-the-middle attack, corrupting the database at the target endpoint without immediate detection.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1493 - Transmitted Data Manipulation

component.name: AWS Glue
component.desc: AWS Glue for data integration.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

countermeasure.name: Assign specific IAM roles to AWS Glue jobs at the time of creation
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and manage permissions efficiently within your AWS Glue environment, assign specific IAM roles to AWS Glue jobs at the time of creation. This practice ensures that each job runs with only the necessary permissions required for its operation, adhering to the principle of least privilege. This minimizes the risk of unauthorized actions and potential security breaches.

Implementation Guidance:

Create an IAM Role for AWS Glue Jobs:

  • Navigate to the IAM console in the AWS Management Console.
  • Choose "Roles" and then "Create role".
  • Select "Glue" as the service that will use the role.
  • Attach the necessary policies that define the permissions for the Glue job. Ensure the policies grant only the permissions required for the job's specific tasks.

Define Permissions Policies:

  • Use managed policies provided by AWS or create custom policies to fine-tune the permissions.

Assign the IAM Role to a Glue Job:

  • When creating a new Glue job in the AWS Glue console, specify the IAM role under the "IAM role" field.
  • For existing jobs, you can update the role by navigating to the job's configuration and editing the "IAM role" field.

Use the AWS CLI or AWS SDKs:

  • You can also assign roles programmatically when creating or updating jobs using the AWS CLI or SDKs.
  • Example using AWS CLI:

aws glue create-job --name MyGlueJob --role arn:aws:iam::account-id:role/GlueJobRole --command 'Name=glueetl,ScriptLocation=s3://my-script-location'

Regularly Review and Rotate IAM Roles:

  • Periodically review the permissions associated with IAM roles to ensure they are still appropriate.
  • Rotate roles and credentials as part of a security best practice to mitigate the risk of compromised credentials.

For more detailed guidance, refer to the AWS Glue Documentation on IAM Roles and the IAM Best Practices.

reference.name: CWE-284: CWE-284
Configuring job properties for Spark jobs in AWS Glue
Security best practices in IAM

countermeasure.name: Implement encryption for the AWS Glue Data Catalog to protect metadata at rest
countermeasure.desc:
AWS Glue Data Catalog encryption provides enhanced security for your sensitive data. AWS Glue integrates with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) to encrypt metadata that's stored in the Data Catalog. You can enable or disable encryption settings for resources in the Data Catalog using the AWS Glue console or the AWS CLI.

When you enable encryption for your Data Catalog, all new objects that you create will be encrypted. When you disable encryption, the new objects you create will not be encrypted, but existing encrypted objects will remain encrypted.

You can encrypt your entire Data Catalog using AWS managed encryption keys or customer managed encryption keys. For more information on key types and states, see AWS Key Management Service concepts in the AWS Key Management Service Developer Guide.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Insufficient access control measures for AWS Glue jobs can lead to unauthorized access and manipulation of data processing activities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Insufficient access control measures for AWS Glue jobs can lead to unauthorized access and manipulation of data processing activities. When permissions are not properly restricted, malicious actors or uninformed users could exploit these permissions to perform unauthorized actions within Glue jobs. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal or external actors with some level of access to the AWS environment may exploit weak or misconfigured IAM roles and policies associated with Glue jobs. This exploitation could be executed through compromised user accounts, overly permissive roles, or inadvertent user error. 
Impacts
The primary impacts include unauthorized data access, data corruption, service disruption, and potential data loss. Confidential or sensitive data could be compromised, leading to reputational damage and regulatory compliance penalties. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An internal user with insufficiently restricted permissions modifies a Glue job to exfiltrate sensitive data to an external location. 
2. A compromised account with access to Glue jobs alters data processing logic, resulting in corrupted or incorrect data outputs. 
3. Overly permissive permissions granted to a third-party contractor allow them to access and manipulate Glue jobs, leading to unintended data exposure.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to metadata in AWS Glue can allow malicious actors to obtain sensitive information
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to metadata in AWS Glue can allow malicious actors to obtain sensitive information about your data catalog, ETL jobs, and other resources. This meta-information can be used to orchestrate further attacks or exfiltrate sensitive data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include external attackers who have gained access through compromised credentials, or internal users with unnecessary permissions. Attack vectors can include exploiting misconfigurations in IAM policies, improper permission settings, or vulnerabilities in the AWS Glue service itself.
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized access to metadata include the potential exposure of sensitive data structures, revealing business-critical information, loss of intellectual property, and the possibility of launching subsequent attacks using the gleaned metadata. It can also lead to a loss of customer trust and regulatory non-compliance.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker obtains credentials from a low-privileged user but finds that IAM policies are misconfigured, allowing access to AWS Glue metadata. The attacker then retrieves details about ETL jobs and uses this information to identify data storage locations to exfiltrate data. 
2. An internal employee with broader-than-necessary permissions accesses metadata about critical ETL jobs and alters the job configurations to reroute sensitive data to an external location under their control. 
3. Exploiting a vulnerability in AWS Glue, an attacker circumvents authentication mechanisms to access metadata directly, gaining insights into the organizations data structures and using this information to identify soft targets for further attacks.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-89
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS encryption for all connections
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that every client-to-database and inter-node communication is encrypted using robust TLS protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2/1.3), thereby mitigating risks such as eavesdropping and man-in-the-middle attacks. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate TLS configuration into the deployment process and enforce these settings via centralized management tools, ensuring that all data exchanged across the network remains confidential and tamper-proof.

Implementation Steps:

Enable TLS Encryption:

  • Configure the Other Data Store to require TLS for all incoming and outgoing connections by setting the appropriate parameters in the configuration files.

Configure Secure Cipher Suites:

  • Enforce the use of modern TLS versions (TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3) and disable deprecated protocols and weak cipher suites to maintain strong encryption standards.

Manage Certificates Securely:

  • Utilize a centralized certificate management system to issue, renew, and revoke TLS certificates, ensuring that all certificates are valid and up-to-date.

Monitor and Audit TLS Usage:

  • Regularly review connection logs and perform security audits to verify that TLS encryption is properly enforced across all connections and to identify any potential misconfigurations.

References:

  • OWASP Transport Layer Protection Cheat Sheet

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Harden configuration and restrict network access
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that the Other Data Store is securely configured and that network access is strictly limited, reducing the system's exposure to potential attacks. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate secure configuration practices into their deployment processes and enforce robust network access controls through firewalls, security groups, or network ACLs. This approach minimizes vulnerabilities, limits the attack surface, and prevents unauthorized access.

Implementation Steps:

Harden Configuration:

  • Disable Unnecessary Services and Features: Remove or disable default settings, services, and features that are not required for your operations to reduce potential points of exploitation.
  • Apply Patches and Updates: Regularly update the database software and its underlying components to incorporate the latest security patches and best practices.
  • Secure Default Settings: Replace default credentials and modify out-of-the-box configurations to adhere to your organization's security policies.

Restrict Network Access:

  • Configure Firewalls and Security Groups: Limit access to the Other Data Store by defining rules that only allow traffic from trusted IP addresses and required ports.
  • Implement Network Segmentation: Place the database in a dedicated subnet or virtual network segment to isolate it from untrusted networks.
  • Monitor and Audit Access: Regularly review access logs and network traffic to detect and respond to unauthorized connection attempts or misconfigurations.

References:

  • NIST Special Publication 800-123: Guide to General Server Security

countermeasure.name: Implement secure backup procedures with encryption and access controls
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that all backup processes for the Other Data Store are secure by encrypting backup data and restricting access to authorized personnel. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate secure backup procedures into the deployment and operational processes to safeguard data against unauthorized access, theft, or accidental loss.

Implementation Steps:

Automate and Schedule Secure Backups:

  • Configure automated backup jobs to run at regular intervals, ensuring data is consistently backed up without manual intervention.
  • Test backups periodically to verify data integrity and the effectiveness of restore procedures.

Encrypt Backup Data:

  • Encrypt Data at Rest: Use strong encryption standards (e.g., AES-256) to secure backup files stored on disk or in cloud storage.
  • Encrypt Data in Transit: Ensure backup data is encrypted during transmission using secure protocols (e.g., TLS) to prevent interception.

Enforce Access Controls:

  • Restrict Access: Implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) to limit backup access to authorized personnel only.
  • Audit Logging: Maintain logs of all backup operations and access attempts for traceability and forensic analysis.

Monitor and Manage Backup Security:

  • Utilize centralized management tools to enforce encryption policies and access controls consistently across backup environments.
  • Regularly review and audit backup configurations and access logs to detect and remediate any security anomalies.

References:

  • NIST Special Publication 800-171

countermeasure.name: Implement strong authentication and role-based access control
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that only authenticated users with appropriate permissions can access the Other Data Store. By combining strong authentication measures with role-based access control (RBAC), developers and DevOps engineers can effectively minimize the risk of unauthorized access and potential data breaches.

Implementation Steps:

Implement Strong Authentication:

  • Enforce Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Require users to provide multiple forms of verification (e.g., password plus a one-time token) before granting access to the database.
  • Adopt Secure Authentication Protocols: Use industry-standard authentication protocols (e.g., OAuth 2.0, SAML, OpenID Connect) to securely manage user credentials.
  • Enforce Password Policies: Require strong, complex passwords and implement regular password updates to reduce the risk of compromise.

Establish Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

  • Define User Roles and Permissions: Create clear roles (e.g., administrator, developer, auditor) and assign the minimum necessary permissions to each role based on the principle of least privilege.
  • Integrate with Centralized Identity Management: Utilize a centralized identity and access management (IAM) system to manage user accounts, roles, and permissions across environments.
  • Automate Role Assignment and Provisioning: Implement automation tools to streamline the assignment, modification, and revocation of roles, ensuring that access is promptly updated as roles change.

Monitor and Audit Access:

  • Log Authentication and Access Events: Capture and analyze logs for all authentication and access activities to identify suspicious behavior or potential breaches.
  • Perform Regular Audits: Periodically review role assignments and access logs to ensure compliance with the least privilege principle and to promptly address any anomalies.

References:

  • OWASP Authentication Cheat Sheet

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)

PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management

countermeasure.name: Regularly update the database to the latest secure version
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that your database remains protected against known vulnerabilities by keeping it up-to-date with the latest security patches and software versions. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate a robust update management process into the deployment and operational workflows to ensure that the database software is regularly evaluated, tested, and upgraded as new versions become available.

Implementation Steps:

Monitor Vendor Releases:

  • Subscribe to vendor security advisories and release notes to stay informed about new patches and updates.

Test and Validate Updates:

  • Validate updates in a staging environment before deploying them to production to ensure compatibility and stability.

Automate the Update Process:

  • Use configuration management tools (e.g., Ansible, Puppet, Chef) to automate the patching process and enforce consistent update policies across environments.

Establish a Regular Update Schedule:

  • Define and adhere to a regular maintenance window for applying updates and patches, ensuring minimal disruption to operations.

Maintain Rollback Mechanisms:

  • Develop and test rollback procedures to quickly revert to a previous version in case an update introduces unexpected issues.

Monitor and Audit:

  • Log and review update activities regularly to ensure compliance with security policies and to identify any anomalies.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-40 Revision 3: Guide to Enterprise Patch Management Technologies

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Use parameterized queries and validate inputs
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that the Other Data Store is protected against injection attacks, such as SQL injection, by enforcing the use of parameterized queries and rigorous input validation. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate these practices into their development workflows to ensure that user inputs are properly sanitized and handled as data rather than executable code.

Implementation Steps:

Use Parameterized Queries:

  • Implement Prepared Statements: Configure your database interactions to use prepared statements or parameterized queries, ensuring that user-supplied input is treated strictly as data.
  • Avoid String Concatenation: Do not construct SQL queries through string concatenation with user input, which can expose the system to injection attacks.

Validate Inputs:

  • Sanitize User Inputs: Validate and sanitize all incoming data against expected formats, lengths, and types using server-side validation techniques.
  • Apply Whitelisting: Use whitelisting approaches to allow only approved characters or patterns, thereby mitigating the risk of malicious input.

Test and Monitor:

  • Regular Code Reviews: Periodically review code to ensure adherence to safe query practices and input validation procedures.
  • Automate Security Testing: Integrate static and dynamic analysis tools to continuously assess and detect injection vulnerabilities.

References:

  • OWASP SQL Injection Prevention Cheat Sheet

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers exploit outdated vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Failure to regularly update the Other Database leaves known vulnerabilities unpatched, enabling attackers to exploit these weaknesses and compromise system security.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, and nation-state actors.
  • Vectors: Automated scans to detect outdated software, use of publicly available exploits, and leveraging SQL injection or remote code execution techniques.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized data access or data breaches.
  • System downtime or service disruption.
  • Compromise of data integrity and potential lateral movement within the network.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker uses an automated tool to scan for the database running an outdated version, then deploys a known exploit to execute remote code.
  2. A hacker exploits a known SQL injection vulnerability in an outdated system to extract sensitive customer data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers exploit misconfigurations in database settings
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Misconfigured database settingssuch as default credentials, improper access controls, or unsecured network endpointscan leave the system vulnerable, allowing attackers to gain unauthorized access, manipulate data, or disrupt services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and insider threats.
  • Vectors: Automated scans for default or weak configurations, brute force attacks on poorly secured accounts, and exploitation of unsecured network interfaces.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Data corruption or deletion.
  • Service disruptions and potential lateral movement within the network.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker identifies a database using default credentials and easily logs in to extract or alter data.
  2. A hacker exploits misconfigured network settings to bypass firewalls, gaining unauthorized administrative access to the database.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Attackers exfiltrate data due to insecure backup procedures
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Inadequate security measures in backup proceduressuch as lack of encryption and improper access controlscan expose sensitive data, allowing attackers to steal backup files and exfiltrate critical information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, insider threats, and state-sponsored actors.
  • Vectors: Exploiting unsecured cloud storage, misconfigured backup systems, or weak access controls to gain unauthorized access to backup data.

Impacts:

  • Exposure of sensitive and confidential data.
  • Financial, legal, and reputational damage.
  • Non-compliance with regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker scans for publicly accessible cloud storage buckets, discovers unencrypted backup files, and downloads sensitive customer data.
  2. An insider abuses lax access controls on backup repositories to copy and exfiltrate confidential business information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service

threat.name: Attackers intercept data due to unencrypted communications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
When communications between clients and the Other Database occur without encryption, data transmitted over the network is exposed. This makes it susceptible to interception by attackers who can capture sensitive information in transit.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, and state-sponsored actors.
  • Vectors: Utilizing packet sniffing tools on unencrypted networks, executing man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, and exploiting unsecured Wi-Fi or legacy communication protocols.

Impacts:

  • Exposure of sensitive or confidential data.
  • Potential identity theft, financial loss, and privacy breaches.
  • Increased risk of subsequent attacks due to compromised credentials.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker intercepts unencrypted traffic on a public Wi-Fi network, capturing login credentials and personal data during a client-to-database transaction.
  2. A man-in-the-middle attack is executed on a system that uses unencrypted HTTP connections, allowing the attacker to modify or eavesdrop on critical communications.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access due to weak authentication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Weak authentication mechanisms, such as the absence of multi-factor authentication, simple passwords, or outdated protocols, can enable attackers to bypass security controls and gain unauthorized access to the database. This compromises the integrity and confidentiality of the data stored.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and insider threats.
  • Vectors: Brute-force attacks, credential stuffing, social engineering, and exploitation of default or easily guessable credentials.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive or confidential data.
  • Data manipulation, exfiltration, or deletion.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within the network and subsequent security breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker uses automated tools to perform a brute-force attack on a database account protected by a weak password, eventually gaining administrative access.
  2. A hacker leverages stolen credentials from a previous breach to access the database, exploiting the absence of multi-factor authentication to bypass security measures.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers exploit SQL injection vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
SQL injection vulnerabilities occur when user input is improperly sanitized, allowing attackers to inject malicious SQL code into queries. This can lead to unauthorized data access, data manipulation, or complete system compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and script kiddies.
  • Vectors: Exploiting unsanitized input fields in web applications, abusing vulnerable API endpoints, and leveraging automated tools to identify and attack SQL injection flaws.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Data manipulation, deletion, or corruption.
  • Potential escalation of privileges and broader network compromise.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker inputs malicious SQL code into a web form that lacks proper sanitization, retrieving confidential customer records from the database.
  2. A hacker exploits a vulnerable API endpoint to inject SQL commands that alter or delete critical data, causing significant service disruption.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-477: Use of Obsolete Function The code uses deprecated or obsolete functions, which suggests that the code has not been actively reviewed or maintained.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Ensure secure communication
countermeasure.desc:
Enforce HTTPS:

  • Configure your server to serve content exclusively over HTTPS, redirecting all HTTP requests to HTTPS. This ensures data is encrypted during transit.
  • Utilize HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) to instruct browsers to only communicate with the server using secure HTTPS connections.

Validate SSL/TLS Certificates:

  • Ensure your server uses a valid SSL/TLS certificate from a reputable Certificate Authority (CA). This confirms the server's identity to clients.
  • Implement certificate pinning in your client-side application to only trust certificates matching a specific hash. This protects against MITM attacks using fraudulent certificates.

Secure TLS Configuration:

  • Use strong ciphers: Configure your server to use strong encryption ciphers and protocols. Avoid deprecated protocols like SSLv3 and weak ciphers.
  • Regularly update your server's TLS configuration based on the latest security standards and recommendations, such as those provided by the SSL Labs' SSL Test or Mozilla's SSL Configuration Generator.

Fallback Scenarios:

  • Implement logic to handle secure fallback scenarios. If a secure connection cannot be established, do not fallback to insecure protocols or encryption standards.
  • Provide clear messaging to the user when a secure connection cannot be established, advising them of potential security risks.
