customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers can bypass permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Improperly implemented or enforced server-side permissions allow attackers to bypass access controls and gain unauthorized access to restricted resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers exploiting vulnerabilities in the applications logic.
  • Malicious Insiders using knowledge to bypass permission checks.
  • Misconfigured RBAC or API endpoints that fail to enforce proper access checks.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Potential data breaches, legal consequences, and reputation damage.
  • Privilege escalation and unauthorized actions, such as data modification.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker exploits a flaw to access restricted user data.
  2. A user manipulates parameters to escalate privileges and access admin functions.
  3. Misconfigured RBAC grants unauthorized users access to sensitive resources.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1196 - Control Panel Items

threat.name: Attackers can exploit vulnerable components
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Vulnerable components, such as outdated libraries, frameworks, or services, can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access or execute malicious actions. These vulnerabilities can allow attackers to compromise the system, steal data, or cause service disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers exploiting known vulnerabilities in third-party libraries or components.
  • Malicious Insiders taking advantage of unpatched components to escalate privileges or exfiltrate data.
  • Automated Tools used by attackers to scan for and exploit known vulnerabilities in components.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data or system controls.
  • Potential for remote code execution or privilege escalation.
  • Service downtime, data corruption, or loss.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker exploits a vulnerability in a third-party library used by the application to execute remote code.
  2. A malicious insider exploits an unpatched component to escalate privileges and access sensitive data.
  3. An attacker uses an automated vulnerability scanner to identify and exploit outdated software components, gaining unauthorized access to the application.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers can exploit unsafe XML parsers
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Unsafe XML parsers can be exploited when processing XML data that contains malicious payloads. Attackers can craft specially designed XML documents to trigger denial of service (DoS) attacks, or even cause arbitrary code execution or data exfiltration by exploiting vulnerabilities in the XML parser.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers submitting malicious XML input to the application in an attempt to exploit parser vulnerabilities.
  • Malicious Insiders using knowledge of the system to craft dangerous XML payloads that bypass security controls.
  • Unvalidated Input passed to the XML parser from untrusted sources, which can be manipulated to cause unexpected behavior.

Impacts:

  • Denial of service (DoS) due to resource exhaustion (e.g., XML billion laughs attack).
  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data or execution of arbitrary code.
  • System crashes, data corruption, or service disruptions from incorrectly parsed XML data.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker submits a malicious XML document containing an entity expansion attack, causing the server to exhaust resources and crash.
  2. A crafted XML payload is parsed by an unsafe XML parser, resulting in the execution of arbitrary code on the server.
  3. An attacker exploits an unvalidated XML input field, causing the server to parse and leak sensitive information or bypass security checks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1133 - External Remote Services

threat.name: Attackers can intercept or leak sensitive data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
When sensitive data is transmitted or stored without proper encryption or security controls, attackers can intercept or leak this information, leading to unauthorized access, data theft, or exposure. This can occur due to weak encryption, misconfigurations, or inadequate security measures in place to protect sensitive data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers intercepting unencrypted data during transmission using methods like man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks.
  • Malicious Insiders with access to improperly secured data, exploiting their privileges to leak or steal information.
  • Weak Encryption or outdated cryptographic methods that fail to secure sensitive data during transit or at rest.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data, including personal, financial, or proprietary information.
  • Data breaches, leading to regulatory fines, reputational damage, and loss of customer trust.
  • Potential for identity theft, financial fraud, or further exploitation of leaked data.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker intercepts sensitive information (e.g., login credentials or personal data) transmitted over an unencrypted HTTP connection.
  2. A malicious insider accesses and leaks confidential data stored in plaintext or improperly encrypted in a database.
  3. A man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacker exploits weak SSL/TLS configurations, intercepting and decrypting sensitive data being transmitted between a client and server.

threat.name: Attackers can exploit insecure configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Insecure configurations, such as weak security settings, improper access control, or default settings, can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access or disrupt services. These vulnerabilities often arise from human error, insufficient hardening, or failure to review configurations regularly.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers exploiting misconfigured security settings or services exposed to the internet.
  • Malicious Insiders abusing poorly configured systems or excessive permissions.
  • Automated Scanning Tools that detect default or weak configurations and exploit them for unauthorized access.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive resources or data.
  • Compromise of system integrity or potential remote code execution.
  • Increased attack surface, leading to easier exploitation by attackers.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker exploits a service left with default credentials or misconfigured access controls, gaining unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  2. A misconfigured firewall allows an attacker to bypass security and access a vulnerable internal application.
  3. An insecure API configuration exposes critical functions to the public, allowing attackers to exploit them for malicious purposes.

threat.name: Attackers can abuse server-side requests
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Server-side request forgery (SSRF) occurs when an attacker is able to manipulate a server to make unintended requests to internal or external services, potentially accessing sensitive data, or causing the server to perform malicious actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers submitting crafted requests that the server forwards to other internal services, allowing access to protected resources.
  • Misconfigured Input Validation that allows an attacker to control the servers outbound requests, exploiting it to interact with internal systems.
  • Exploiting SSRF in web services that process requests and interact with databases, internal APIs, or other resources.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to internal resources or sensitive data.
  • Remote code execution or data exfiltration via internal services.
  • Service disruption, denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, or system misconfiguration.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker crafts a request that causes the server to query internal resources, exposing sensitive database information.
  2. A malicious actor abuses an SSRF vulnerability to interact with a backend service that should only be accessible internally, potentially leading to a data breach.
  3. An attacker uses SSRF to trigger unnecessary requests, causing internal services to overload or crash, leading to a denial of service.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Attackers can evade detection without proper logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Without proper logging and monitoring, attackers can evade detection while performing malicious actions on a system. Insufficient or misconfigured logging can prevent timely identification of suspicious activities, making it harder to respond to security incidents or identify compromised systems.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers exploiting the absence of detailed logging to perform malicious activities without leaving traces.
  • Malicious Insiders manipulating or disabling logging to avoid detection while exfiltrating data or modifying critical systems.
  • Misconfiguration of logging settings that leads to incomplete or missing logs, allowing attackers to act without being recorded.

Impacts:

  • Undetected data breaches, system compromises, or malicious actions.
  • Delayed or ineffective incident response due to lack of actionable logs.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within the system by attackers, exploiting gaps in logging and monitoring.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker compromises an internal server and performs actions (e.g., data exfiltration or privilege escalation) without triggering any alarms because logging is disabled or misconfigured.
  2. A malicious insider disables logging mechanisms, covering their tracks while accessing and modifying sensitive data.
  3. An attacker exploits an application vulnerability to gain access to critical systems, but the lack of proper logging prevents detection of the breach for an extended period.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers can compromise sessions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Session hijacking or fixation occurs when attackers are able to gain unauthorized access to a user's session by stealing or predicting session identifiers. This can happen if session management is insecure, allowing attackers to impersonate legitimate users and access sensitive data or perform unauthorized actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers using techniques like session sniffing, cross-site scripting (XSS), or man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks to steal session tokens.
  • Malicious Insiders exploiting weak session management practices to impersonate other users.
  • Weak Session Tokens or improper session expiration policies that leave sessions vulnerable to hijacking.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to user accounts, sensitive data, or system resources.
  • Potential data breaches, financial fraud, or further exploitation of compromised accounts.
  • Loss of trust and reputational damage due to security lapses in session management.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker intercepts an unencrypted session token in transit using a MITM attack, gaining access to the victims account.
  2. A malicious script injected via XSS steals the session cookie from a user, allowing the attacker to impersonate them and access sensitive data.
  3. An attacker guesses or reuses a predictable session ID to take over a valid user session and perform unauthorized actions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1075 - Pass the Hash

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers can run malicious code via deserialization
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Deserialization vulnerabilities occur when an attacker is able to modify or inject malicious code into serialized data, which is then deserialized by the application. This can lead to arbitrary code execution, privilege escalation, or other malicious actions if the deserialization process is not securely handled.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers sending specially crafted data to exploit deserialization vulnerabilities in an application.
  • Malicious Insiders manipulating serialized data for malicious purposes.
  • Weak Input Validation or improper handling of deserialization routines, allowing attackers to inject harmful payloads into serialized objects.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized execution of malicious code on the system, leading to data breaches, system compromise, or loss of integrity.
  • Elevation of privileges or unauthorized access to system resources.
  • Disruption of application functionality or service downtime caused by the execution of malicious code.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker exploits a deserialization vulnerability to inject a payload that allows them to execute arbitrary code and gain unauthorized access to a server.
  2. A crafted serialized object is submitted via an API, causing the system to deserialize the object and execute malicious commands, compromising sensitive data.
  3. An attacker manipulates deserialized data in a web application, leading to remote code execution or privilege escalation within the system.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services

threat.name: Attackers can manipulate business workflows
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Business workflow manipulation occurs when attackers exploit vulnerabilities in a systems process or logic to alter or disrupt normal business operations. By tampering with workflows, attackers can cause unauthorized actions, misroute data, or manipulate processes to benefit malicious goals, leading to business disruption, financial loss, or reputational damage.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers exploiting vulnerabilities in workflow logic or APIs to alter business operations.
  • Malicious Insiders with knowledge of internal workflows who intentionally or accidentally manipulate business processes.
  • Weak Access Control or improperly secured workflows that allow unauthorized users to perform actions outside their role or authorization.

Impacts:

  • Disruption of critical business operations, leading to financial or operational losses.
  • Unauthorized transactions or misappropriation of resources.
  • Damage to system integrity, data corruption, or data leakage due to workflow manipulation.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker manipulates an online order workflow to reroute shipments to an unauthorized address, causing financial losses or theft.
  2. A malicious insider alters approval workflows to bypass legitimate checks and approve fraudulent transactions.
  3. An attacker exploits a vulnerability in an automated approval system, causing unauthorized changes to sensitive business data or operations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer

threat.name: Attackers can inject scripts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Script injection, such as Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), occurs when attackers inject malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users. These scripts are executed in the context of a user's browser, potentially leading to unauthorized access, data theft, or malicious actions on behalf of the victim.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers injecting malicious scripts into input fields, URLs, or other entry points that get executed by other users' browsers.
  • Malicious Insiders exploiting poor input validation or output encoding to inject harmful scripts that compromise user sessions or steal sensitive data.
  • Insecure Web Applications failing to properly sanitize or escape user inputs, leaving the application vulnerable to script injection.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to user data, session hijacking, or credential theft through malicious scripts.
  • Data manipulation or destruction by executing harmful scripts on the client-side.
  • Loss of user trust and reputational damage if malicious scripts are used to exploit vulnerabilities.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker injects a malicious script into a comment form that, when viewed by other users, steals their session cookies and sends them to the attacker.
  2. A user is tricked into clicking a link containing a script that injects malicious code into the web page, compromising their account or triggering unauthorized actions.
  3. An attacker exploits an input field on an admin panel to inject a script that alters data or performs unauthorized actions within the application.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

threat.name: Attackers can inject malicious commands
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Command injection occurs when attackers can inject malicious commands into an application, typically through input fields that are not properly sanitized. These commands are executed by the system, allowing attackers to gain unauthorized access, execute arbitrary code, or perform destructive actions on the system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External Attackers injecting malicious code via input fields, query parameters, or other entry points in the application.
  • Malicious Insiders exploiting vulnerabilities to execute commands that affect the integrity or availability of the system.
  • Weak Input Validation or improper handling of user input, allowing attackers to craft commands that the system executes.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized execution of commands that compromise system integrity, data, or access.
  • Potential for system crashes, data corruption, or unauthorized data retrieval.
  • Further exploitation of compromised systems for escalating privileges or launching attacks.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker injects a command through an unsanitized input field, gaining access to the underlying database and retrieving sensitive data.
  2. Malicious input is submitted via an HTTP request that allows the attacker to execute shell commands, altering the servers configuration.
  3. An attacker exploits a vulnerable API endpoint to inject commands that cause the application to crash or execute unauthorized actions, disrupting service.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-682
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-682: Incorrect Calculation The product performs a calculation that generates incorrect or unintended results that are later used in security-critical decisions or resource management. When product performs a security-critical calculation incorrectly, it might lead to incorrect resource allocations, incorrect privilege assignments, or failed comparisons among other things. Many of the direct results of an incorrect calculation can lead to even larger problems such as failed protection mechanisms or even arbitrary code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-697
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-697: Incorrect Comparison The product compares two entities in a security-relevant context, but the comparison is incorrect, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.

countermeasure.name: Adopt capacity-aware, multi-Availability Zone placement strategies
countermeasure.desc:
Step-by-Step Guidance for Implementing the Countermeasure:

1. Use Multiple Instance Types and Launch Templates

To reduce potential disruptions caused by infrastructure limitations within a single Availability Zone (AZ), leverage multiple EC2 instance types and launch templates:

  • Analyze workload requirements to select compatible EC2 instance families/types that meet compute, memory, storage, and networking needs.
  • Create launch templates for each instance type, specifying key configuration details such as AMI, instance type, security group, and block device mappings. Follow AWS Launch Template Guidance for detailed instructions.
  • Test launch templates in your development environment to confirm compatibility and performance.

2. Configure Auto Scaling Groups Across Multiple Availability Zone Subnets

To achieve high availability and fault tolerance, distribute workloads across multiple subnets tied to different AZs.

  • Identify subnets associated with distinct AZs within your VPC. Ensure your VPC is configured correctly (Subnet Documentation).
  • Create or update Auto Scaling Groups (ASGs) to span these subnets, specifying multiple AZs during ASG configuration.
  • Set ASG scaling policies based on workload demand or health checks to dynamically allocate resources.

3. Monitor and Plan Service Quotas Per Availability Zone

AWS imposes quotas on resources per region and AZ, which can lead to capacity constraints. To avoid service disruptions:

  • Use the AWS Service Quotas dashboard to monitor quotas for critical resources like EC2 instances, EBS volumes, and Elastic IPs.
  • Plan resource allocations carefully while scaling across AZs and request quota increases as needed using AWS Service Quotas Console.
  • Automate monitoring of service quotas using Amazon CloudWatch.

4. Validate That Critical Workloads Can Start in Alternate Availability Zones

Ensure failover capabilities for critical workloads in case one AZ becomes unavailable:

  • Test the deployment of your applications in alternate AZs by simulating failure scenarios.
  • Review resource dependencies (e.g., EBS volumes and IP addresses) and ensure configurations allow for quick replication or reassignment in another AZ.
  • Create Disaster Recovery (DR) plans to guide workloads' transition within minutes of AZ disruptions.

5. Continuously Evaluate and Audit Configuration

Regularly audit your architecture and workload distribution across AZs to identify security and operational risks.

  • Use AWS Config to set up rules for continuous compliance checks.
  • Review AWS Trusted Advisor recommendations to optimize availability configurations and verify AZ balance.
  • Conduct routine penetration testing and failure drills for detecting vulnerabilities and validating failover mechanisms.

References

  • AWS EC2 Availability Zones Documentation
  • AWS Global Infrastructure
  • AWS EC2 Launch Templates
  • AWS Service Quotas
  • Amazon CloudWatch
  • AWS Config

RS.CO-4: Coordination with stakeholders occurs consistent with response plans

countermeasure.name: Constrain egress per Availability Zone using NAT, routes, and endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
Step 1: Deploy NAT Gateways Per Availability Zone

To ensure high availability and fault tolerance, deploy a NAT Gateway in each Availability Zone within your VPC.

  • Navigate to the Amazon VPC console.
  • In the navigation pane, select NAT Gateways and then click Create NAT Gateway.
  • Select the subnet corresponding to the Availability Zone where the NAT Gateway will reside.
  • Allocate or select an Elastic IP address to associate with the NAT Gateway.
  • Repeat this process for all relevant Availability Zones in your VPC.

Step 2: Bind Private Subnets to Same-Zone NAT Gateways

Assign route tables to private subnets and ensure traffic destined for the internet is routed through NAT Gateways in the same Availability Zone.

  • In the Amazon VPC console, select Route Tables.
  • Choose a route table associated with a private subnet.
  • Edit routes to add a destination of 0.0.0.0/0 and set the target to the NAT Gateway's ID specific to the same Availability Zone.
  • Associate the route table with the private subnet in the Subnet Associations tab.
  • Repeat these steps for all private subnets to ensure zonal redundancy.

Step 3: Restrict Egress with Route Tables and Network ACLs

Limit the outbound traffic from private subnets to the minimum necessary to reduce the attack surface.

  • Configure the route table to direct only necessary traffic to specific destinations via the NAT Gateway.
  • Set up Network ACLs (NACLs) to explicitly allow specific protocols, ports, and IP ranges necessary for your applications.
  • Ensure a default "Deny" rule for other outbound traffic.

Step 4: Prefer VPC Endpoints for AWS Service Traffic

Leverage VPC endpoints (interface or gateway endpoints) to route traffic to AWS services directly within the AWS network, avoiding public internet routes.

  • Navigate to the Amazon VPC console and select Endpoints.
  • Click Create Endpoint and select the desired AWS service, such as S3 or DynamoDB.
  • Choose the appropriate Endpoint type (gateway or interface) based on the service.
  • Associate the endpoint with the relevant route tables within your VPC.
  • Test and verify traffic to AWS services flows through the endpoint instead of the NAT Gateway.

References

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • Amazon VPC NAT Gateway Documentation
  • Amazon VPC Endpoints Documentation
  • Network ACLs Documentation

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Design multi-Availability Zone architectures for fault isolation
countermeasure.desc:
To improve the security and resiliency of your workload in AWS, follow the step-by-step guidance below for distributing critical resources across multiple Availability Zones (AZs):

  1. Determine the number of Availability Zones and Regions: Analyze the workload requirements to identify suitable AWS Regions and the number of Availability Zones available in each Region. Refer to the AWS Availability Zone documentation to find detailed information.
  2. Create separate subnets for each Availability Zone: Design your Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) with subnets distributed across multiple AZs. Each AZ should have a dedicated subnet to ensure proper resource isolation and failover capabilities. Follow the guidelines in the AWS VPC User Guide for subnet creation.
  3. Configure Auto Scaling Groups across multiple subnets: Create an Auto Scaling Group (ASG) and specify the subnets in multiple AZs to ensure instances can launch in alternative AZs during an outage. Enable dynamic scaling policies to maintain a consistent level of performance. Review the AWS Auto Scaling documentation for step-by-step setup instructions.
  4. Use Multi-AZ deployments for managed services: For database services like Amazon RDS, enable Multi-AZ deployment to provision a standby replica in a secondary AZ. This setup automatically performs failover during disruptions. Additionally, validate Multi-AZ support for other managed services, such as Amazon ElastiCache and Amazon DynamoDB. Use the Amazon RDS Multi-AZ documentation for more information.
  5. Implement replication across Availability Zones: Configure data replication mechanisms that span AZs for critical datasets. For example, enable S3 cross-region replication or use the replication features provided by databases like Amazon DynamoDB Global Tables and Amazon Aurora. Reference the Amazon S3 Replication documentation.
  6. Validate failover and recovery processes: Conduct periodic failover testing to ensure seamless transitions during AZ outages. Validate that your Auto Scaling Groups, Multi-AZ services, and data replication mechanisms work as intended under simulated failure scenarios. Review AWS Well-Architected Framework guidelines for best practices.
  7. Monitor AZ health and implement alerts: Use AWS CloudWatch to monitor the performance and health of resources across AZs. Create alarms to detect anomalies or failures early, and set up SNS notifications to ensure real-time alerts for critical events. Refer to the Amazon CloudWatch documentation for guidance.
  8. Optimize cost and compliance considerations: Ensure your workload is distributed efficiently to avoid unnecessary costs while adhering to regional compliance requirements. Use AWS Cost Explorer and AWS Config to maintain visibility into cost and security configurations. Refer to the AWS Cost Explorer documentation.

References

  • AWS Availability Zones in EC2
  • AWS Global Infrastructure and Availability Zones
  • AWS VPC User Guide
  • Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling
  • Amazon RDS Multi-AZ

countermeasure.name: Harden per-Availability Zone network segmentation
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps to implement the security countermeasure for AWS Availability Zones effectively:

  1. Design the Subnet Architecture:
    • Create distinct public and private subnets in each Availability Zone within your VPC.
    • Ensure public subnets are used for resources requiring internet access, such as load balancers.
    • Place resources such as application servers or databases in private subnets to prevent direct internet exposure.
  2. Configure Security Groups:
    • Apply the principle of least privilege when creating and configuring security groups. Ensure they allow only explicitly required traffic.
    • Examples: Restrict access to application servers to specific IP ranges or allow database ports only from application servers.
    • Allocate separate security groups for different resource tiers (e.g., web, application, database).
  3. Set Up Network Access Control Lists (NACLs):
    • Create NACLs for subnets to define fine-grained network-level policies for inbound and outbound traffic.
    • Implement deny rules for traffic that must explicitly be blocked, alongside allowing necessary traffic.
    • Regularly review NACL rules to optimize security settings.
  4. Create Dedicated Route Tables:
    • Assign dedicated route tables for each subnet tier to ensure isolation and control over routing.
    • Public subnets route tables should include routes to an internet gateway (IGW), allowing internet-based communication.
    • Private subnets should have routes directing traffic through a NAT gateway or VPC endpoint, without routing traffic to the IGW.
  5. Leverage VPC Endpoints:
    • Use VPC endpoints to privately access AWS services such as S3, DynamoDB, or Systems Manager without the need for public internet access.
    • Subnet traffic directed to VPC endpoints will stay entirely within the AWS network, improving security.
    • Ensure proper IAM policies on the VPC endpoints to enforce access controls for the associated AWS service.
  6. Regularly Review Routes:
    • Inspect route tables periodically to identify any unintended routes that may expose resources to unauthorized access or create conflicts.
    • Remove unnecessary routes and test changes thoroughly before deployment.
    • Monitor changes in route tables using AWS Config to ensure compliance with your network security policies.

For further details and best practices, consult the following references:

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • AWS Infrastructure Security Basics

countermeasure.name: Implement Availability Zone-scoped logging and monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Step-by-Step Guidance for Implementing the Security Countermeasure:

1. Enable VPC Flow Logs for Each Subnet

VPC Flow Logs provide visibility into the IP traffic handled by your VPC. By enabling flow logs at the subnet level, you gain granular insights into traffic patterns and potential issues.

  • Log into the AWS Management Console.
  • Navigate to the VPC section of the console.
  • Select the target VPC and then locate the specific subnets within it.
  • Click on the subnet you want to enable logs for and choose Create Flow Log.
  • Specify the destination for the logs (e.g., CloudWatch Logs or an Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Choose appropriate filters (e.g., All, Accept, Reject).
  • Save your settings and repeat for all relevant subnets.

2. Enable AWS CloudTrail Across All Regions

AWS CloudTrail provides event history and auditing capabilities for actions occurring within your AWS account. You should ensure CloudTrail is globally enabled and centralized for all regions.

  • Navigate to the CloudTrail console.
  • Click Create trail.
  • Provide a name for your trail and enable logging across All Regions.
  • Specify where logs should be stored (e.g., an Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Configure optional encryption and permission settings for enhanced security.
  • Validate the trail creation and ensure monitoring is enabled for Availability Zone activity.

3. Centralize Logs in Amazon CloudWatch Metrics/Alarms

To gain insights into anomalous traffic behavior and monitor configuration drift, integrate logs with CloudWatch and set up metrics and alarms with dimensions for Availability Zones.

  • Navigate to the CloudWatch console.
  • Ensure you have enabled log ingestion from VPC Flow Logs and AWS CloudTrail.
  • Inside the console, create Log Groups to centralize logs related to traffic patterns in specific Availability Zones.
  • Define Metric Filters to extract key metrics from logs, such as large spikes in denied traffic or unexpected changes.
  • Create alarms using CloudWatch thresholds to alert when unusual behavior is identified.
  • Test alarms and validate their alignment with Availability Zone identifiers.

4. Continuously Monitor for Configuration Drift

Configuration drift occurs when the infrastructure gradually diverges from its intended state. Detect and mitigate it using AWS Config and automated corrective actions.

  • Enable AWS Config to monitor resource configurations across your account.
  • Use Config rules to track compliance with security best practices, focusing on VPC security, flow logs, and trail settings.
  • Create custom Config rules to log and alert for changes in subnet configurations or flow log status.
  • Integrate relevant insights into CloudWatch dashboards for centralized visibility.

5. Detect Anomalous Traffic Patterns

Leverage specific AWS tools to detect unusual or harmful traffic patterns across Availability Zones.

  • Integrate Amazon GuardDuty to analyze flow logs and CloudTrail events for threats.
  • Enable DNS threat detection and monitor unusual spikes or requests within Availability Zones.
  • Regularly audit metric alarms and identify high-traffic periods that dont correlate with expected behavior.
  • Implement runtime protection tools to respond to live traffic anomalies.

References

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • AWS Infrastructure Security Basics
  • VPC Flow Logs User Guide
  • CloudTrail Console User Guide
  • Amazon CloudWatch Logs Monitoring
  • What Is AWS Config?
  • What is Amazon GuardDuty?

countermeasure.name: Restrict inter-Availability Zone connectivity with least privilege
countermeasure.desc:
To improve the security of AWS Availability Zone implementations, follow these comprehensive steps:

  1. Scope Security Group Rules to Necessary Ports and Sources:

    • Decide which ports are required based on the specific functionality of the application or workloads hosted within the Availability Zone.
    • Restrict inbound and outbound traffic to only the ranges of IPs or VPC resources that require access.
    • For each security group, use precise CIDR ranges or specific AWS resources (i.e., other security groups or instance IDs) to define allowed traffic. Ensure the rules comply with the principle of least privilege.
    • Review the configurations frequently to ensure that only necessary access is permitted and to detect any unused or overly permissive rules.
    • To implement, navigate to the Security Groups section in your AWS Management Console or use the AWS CLI/SDK.

  2. Segment Tiers per Availability Zone:

    • Design your application tiers (e.g., web, app, and database tiers) to align with specific Availability Zones. This provides a natural layer of segmentation for additional security.
    • Configure security group rules to ensure that lateral movement is restricted between tiers, except for explicitly required communication flows. For example, only allow the application tier to communicate with the database tier.
    • Use subnet segmentation within Availability Zones to isolate traffic dynamically based on the application tier's role. Each tier can be assigned its own subnet with distinct configurations.

  3. Use ALB/NLB Target Groups with Controlled Registration Across Zones:

    • Configure Target Groups in your Application Load Balancer (ALB) or Network Load Balancer (NLB) to register instances based on specific Availability Zones.
    • Verify that health checks are configured properly to ensure that only healthy instances are registered in Target Groups.
    • Control registration by tagging or labeling instances according to their purpose and zone, and create IAM policies or scripts for automated instance registration based on exclusion or inclusion criteria.
    • Use listener rules in your ALB or NLB to enforce zone-specific routing if necessary.

  4. Review NACLs to Minimize Lateral Movement:

    • For each subnet in your VPC, review Network Access Control List (NACL) rules to ensure that only legitimate traffic flows are allowed.
    • Block unnecessary intra-zone traffic by explicitly denying overly permissive rules, especially those allowing access between subnets of different tiers unnecessarily.
    • Use deny rules explicitly where feasible to block traffic that should not have lateral access across subnets and Availability Zones.
    • Regularly audit NACL rules using AWS Config to ensure compliance with best practices and monitor for drift or outdated configurations.

References

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • Amazon EC2 Security Groups
  • What Is an Application Load Balancer?
  • Network Load Balancer Overview
  • Network ACL Overview
  • AWS Config Evaluation of Rules

countermeasure.name: Use stable Availability Zone ids and avoid hardcoded names
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure resources in AWS are distributed across distinct physical zones and maintain high availability, adhere to the following steps:

  1. Understand AWS Availability Zone IDs:
    • Availability Zones are distinct from "names" such as us-east-1a. These names vary per account due to internal mapping, but Availability Zone IDs (e.g., use-az1) remain consistent across accounts.
    • Refer to the AWS documentation on Availability Zone IDs to familiarize yourself with this concept: Availability Zone Concepts.
  2. Use Programmatic Discovery via the AWS CLI or SDK to dynamically retrieve Availability Zone information:
    • Run the following AWS CLI command to list all Availability Zones within a region:aws ec2 describe-availability-zones --region REGION_NAMEReplace REGION_NAME with your selected region (e.g., us-east-1).
    • In the output, reference the ZoneId fields (e.g., use-az1). These IDs can be used reliably to distribute resources across distinct physical locations.
  3. Automate Resource Spreading Across Zones:
    • Design your infrastructure to programmatically spread workloads across the unique ZoneId values using orchestration tools such as AWS CloudFormation, AWS SDK (for Python boto3 or Java SDK), or APIs.
    • Create deployment logic to verify that the resources are evenly distributed by cross-checking the ZoneId mappings during deployment or updates.
  4. Document the ZoneId mappings:
    • Maintain a record of Availability Zone IDs and their associated resources for each deployment or major change.
    • Store this documentation securely in a versioned repository or centralized configuration management system, such as AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store or an internal inventory system.
  5. Continuously Audit Resource Placement:
    • Periodically run the DescribeAvailabilityZones API or CLI command and validate the resource placement against the mapping records for consistency.
    • Update deployment documentation promptly if new zones are added or existing ones are modified.

References

  • Availability Zone Concepts

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Single Availability Zone dependency causing regional service outage impact
threat.desc:
General threat description
Workloads located in a single AWS Availability Zone are exposed to disruptions resulting from zonal failures, scheduled maintenance, or capacity constraints, posing risks to service continuity and data accessibility.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Zonal failures may arise from natural disasters, hardware malfunctions, or network issues. Planned maintenance or sudden demand spikes may also contribute to decreased availability.
Impacts
The impacts include potential outages, temporary or permanent loss of data, degradation of application performance, and loss of trust or revenue resulting from service disruptions.
Example Attack Scenarios
A hardware failure within an Availability Zone causes a widespread outage, bringing down critical applications hosted in that zone. Alternatively, a planned maintenance event reduces resource availability, resulting in service degradation for all workloads relying exclusively on that zone.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Availability Zone identifier mismatch across accounts causing misplacement
threat.desc:
General threat description
Hardcoding the names of Availability Zones can lead to resources being placed in unintended physical zones due to the variability in how names map to physical zones across accounts, which can compromise redundancy and failover strategies.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unintentional misconfiguration by developers or operators, reliance on incorrect documentation, or automated deployment scripts that do not account for differing zone mappings.
Impacts
Potential lack of high availability, increased risk of resource failure in disasters, and compromised system reliability due to violated redundancy and failover assumptions.
Example Attack Scenarios
A developer deploys instances to us-east-1a, assuming it corresponds to a specific physical zone across all accounts, but the mapping differs in their organizations AWS account, placing resources in the same physical zone as other critical systems. A failure in this zone leads to a cascading outage.

threat.name: Capacity and placement risk within an Availability Zone
threat.desc:
General threat description
Zonal capacity constraints or inflexible placement strategies can restrict the ability to scale or perform failovers during disruptions, leading to system downtime or reduced service availability.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Misconfigurations, resource limitations, or improper distribution of workloads can exacerbate zonal constraints and lack of effective placement mechanisms.
Impacts
Reduced service availability, inability to recover from disruptions, and potential customer dissatisfaction due to reliability issues.
Example Attack Scenarios
A sudden increase in resource demand overwhelms a specific Availability Zone, and the inability to migrate workloads to another zone results in degraded performance or service outages. Alternatively, rigid placement strategies restrict scalability, preventing efficient allocation of resources across zones during high loads.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Subnet and route misconfiguration exposing Availability Zone resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) design can lead to unintended exposure of instances or services within an Availability Zone to networks or the internet, compromising isolation and security.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit shared route tables, misconfigured public subnets meant to be private, or overly permissive network ACLs to gain unauthorized access or disrupt services.
Impacts
Potential impacts include data breaches, unauthorized access, service disruptions, or exploitation of exposed resources for malicious activities.
Example Attack Scenarios
An organization accidentally configures a public subnet instead of a private one, inadvertently exposing critical services to the internet. Attackers notice and exploit misconfigured ACLs to access sensitive data or disrupt internal services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Cross-Availability Zone traffic exposure due to broad network rules
threat.desc:
General threat description
Overly permissive configurations in security groups or network ACLs can inadvertently create unintended cross-Availability Zone access paths, potentially increasing the impact of a compromise and expanding the blast radius.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or misconfigured resources can exploit permissive settings to traverse networks across zones, accessing unauthorized systems or data in other Availability Zones.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, service disruptions, and escalation of security incidents across multiple zones, reducing the isolation benefits of Availability Zones.
Example Attack Scenarios
A misconfigured database in one zone with an overly permissive security group gets exploited by an attacker, who then pivots to access sensitive systems in other zones through unintended network paths, amplifying the impact of the event.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1133 - External Remote Services

threat.name: Uncontrolled internet egress from Availability Zone subnets
threat.desc:
General threat description
Instances in private subnets of an Availability Zone may inadvertently access the internet through shared NAT gateways or misconfigured routing, potentially exposing them to risks such as data exfiltration or unauthorized command-and-control activities if outbound traffic is not strictly controlled per zone.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit misconfigured routing tables, overly permissive NAT gateway rules, or unmonitored outbound traffic within the private subnets to establish unauthorized communication channels with external entities.
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive data, unauthorized remote control of instances, or exploitation of the infrastructure for malicious activity, which could lead to financial, reputational, and operational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker might exploit a misconfigured routing table to redirect traffic from instances to a malicious server on the internet, extracting sensitive information. Alternatively, compromised instances could use a shared NAT gateway to contact a command-and-control server, initiating further attacks or lateral movement within the environment.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Insufficient Availability Zone-aware logging and visibility
threat.desc:
General threat description
Insufficient logging and monitoring granularity associated with Availability Zones can hinder prompt identification and management of zonal faults, unauthorized lateral movement, or configuration errors, weakening the efficacy of incident response.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers exploiting gaps in logging to move laterally between zones or leveraging undetected misconfigurations to compromise security.
Impacts
Delayed detection of security concerns, reduced incident response times, and increased potential for extensive damage or data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An undetected misconfiguration in one zone allows unauthorized access, and the lack of granular monitoring enables an attacker to move laterally to compromise other zones without being noticed.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services

component.name: HDFS
component.desc: HDFS (Hadoop Distributed File System) in the Local DC.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

countermeasure.name: Conduct regular configuration reviews and apply updates across all systems
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard your Distributed File System (DFS) against emerging threats and ensure optimal performance, its crucial to conduct regular reviews and updates of system configurations. This practice helps in identifying misconfigurations, ensuring compliance with security policies, and applying necessary patches or updates. Follow these actionable steps, designed to be accessible for developers without previous security experience:

Step 1: Establish a Configuration Baseline

Document Current Configurations: Create a detailed record of the current configurations of your DFS. Include network settings, access controls, encryption settings, and any custom configurations.

Define Configuration Standards: Based on security best practices, regulatory requirements, and the specific needs of your organization, define a set of standard configurations for your DFS.

Step 2: Implement Configuration Management Tools

Choose Configuration Management Software: Utilize configuration management tools (e.g., Ansible, Chef, Puppet, or Terraform) to automate the deployment and management of your DFS configurations. These tools can help ensure consistency and ease the process of rolling out configuration changes.

Automate Configuration Deployments: Set up scripts or templates that apply your defined standard configurations automatically. This reduces human error and ensures that all components of your DFS adhere to the desired configuration state.

Step 3: Schedule Regular Reviews

Plan Regular Configuration Audits: Schedule periodic audits of your DFS configurations. These should be frequent enough to catch issues early, typically quarterly or in response to significant changes in the threat landscape or organizational structure.

Use Automated Scanning Tools: Employ automated tools to scan your DFS for deviations from the baseline configurations or for known vulnerabilities. These tools can provide regular insights into the state of your DFS configurations.

Step 4: Update and Patch Management

Monitor for Updates: Regularly check for updates to your DFS software and any third-party components it relies on. This includes security patches, performance improvements, and new features that can enhance security or functionality.

Apply Updates Promptly: Develop a process for testing and deploying updates in a timely manner. Consider the criticality of the update and potential impact on your system to prioritize updates accordingly.

Review Configuration After Updates: After applying updates, review the system configurations to ensure they still align with your configuration standards. Some updates may alter configurations or introduce new settings that need to be adjusted.

Step 5: Document Changes and Maintain an Audit Trail

Maintain Documentation: Keep detailed records of all configuration changes, the reasons behind them, and the results of any audits. This documentation is crucial for troubleshooting, compliance audits, and security investigations.

Regular Training: Ensure that team members responsible for managing and reviewing the DFS configurations are trained on the latest best practices and tools.

Additional Good Security Practices

  • Incident Response Plan: Have an incident response plan that includes procedures for addressing configuration-related security incidents. This should outline steps for investigation, mitigation, and post-incident analysis to prevent future occurrences.
  • Peer Review: Implement a peer review process for significant configuration changes. This can help catch potential issues before they impact the production environment.

Regularly reviewing and updating the configurations of your Distributed File System is a vital security measure that can prevent vulnerabilities, ensure compliance, and maintain the integrity and availability of your system.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt data at rest using AES256 and data in transit using TLS 1.3
countermeasure.desc:
To protect sensitive information stored in a Distributed File System (DFS) and ensure its confidentiality and integrity during transmission, it's essential to implement encryption both for data-at-rest (stored data) and data-in-transit (data being transferred). Follow these steps to effectively encrypt your DFS data:

Data-at-rest Encryption

Choose an Encryption Standard: Opt for industry-standard encryption algorithms, such as AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) with key lengths of at least 256 bits for encrypting your stored data.

Encrypt File System Storage:

  • If your DFS platform offers built-in encryption features, enable these options following the platform's documentation.
  • For file systems without built-in encryption, use third-party encryption tools or libraries that comply with your chosen encryption standard.

Manage Encryption Keys Securely:

  • Use a centralized key management system (KMS) to store, rotate, and manage access to your encryption keys.
  • Ensure that access to the KMS is tightly controlled and audited.

Regularly Audit and Rotate Encryption Keys: Implement a policy for regular key rotation and audit key usage to enhance security further.

Data-in-transit Encryption

Enable TLS/SSL Protocols: For data being transmitted between clients and the DFS or within components of the DFS, enable TLS (Transport Layer Security) or SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) encryption.

Configure Strong Cipher Suites: When setting up TLS/SSL, choose strong cipher suites that offer robust encryption, authentication, and integrity protection. Avoid deprecated protocols like SSLv3 and lower.

Use Certificate Authorities (CAs) for TLS Certificates: Obtain TLS certificates from reputable Certificate Authorities. This ensures that clients can verify the identity of your DFS servers during the handshake process.

Enforce TLS for All Connections: Configure your DFS and any applications interfacing with it to require TLS for all connections, preventing data from being transmitted in clear text.

Additional Good Security Practices

  • Conduct Regular Security Audits: Regularly audit your encryption implementation and configurations to ensure they meet current security standards and practices.
  • Stay Updated on Encryption Standards: Encryption standards and best practices evolve. Stay informed about the latest developments in encryption technology and security threats.
  • Educate Your Team: Ensure that your development and operations teams understand the importance of encryption and are trained in implementing and managing encryption securely.
  • Implement Access Controls: Encryption is just one layer of defense. Combine it with strong access controls to ensure that only authorized users can access or decrypt the data.

By implementing these measures, you will significantly enhance the security of your Distributed File System, protecting sensitive data both at rest and in transit from unauthorized access and potential security threats.

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Enforce access control checks at all system entry points
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing robust access control enforcement in a DFS is crucial to securing sensitive data and ensuring that only authorized users and systems can access or modify the stored information. Follow these steps to effectively enforce access control:

1. Define Access Control Policies

  • Identify Data Sensitivity: Classify data stored within the DFS according to its sensitivity and the potential impact of its unauthorized access or modification.
  • Determine Access Requirements: For each data classification level, define who needs access and what type of access they require (read, write, execute, delete).
  • Create Access Policies: Based on the sensitivity and access requirements, create comprehensive access control policies. Use the principle of least privilege as a guiding principle, ensuring users have only the access they need to perform their duties.

2. Implement Authentication Mechanisms

  • Require Strong Authentication: Enforce strong authentication methods for users and services accessing the DFS. Consider multi-factor authentication (MFA) for highly sensitive data.
  • Service Accounts: Use service accounts with minimal privileges for automated processes or applications requiring access to the DFS.

3. Apply Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)

  • Define Roles: Create roles that correspond to different job functions within your organization, assigning specific access permissions to each role.
  • Assign Users to Roles: Instead of granting permissions directly to users, assign users to appropriate roles. This simplifies management and ensures consistent application of policies.

4. Use Access Control Lists (ACLs)

  • Configure ACLs: For each file or directory within the DFS, configure ACLs that specify which users or roles are granted or denied access and what type of access is allowed.
  • Review and Update Regularly: Periodically review ACLs to ensure they remain correct and relevant, especially when users change roles or leave the organization.

5. Monitor and Audit Access

  • Implement Logging: Enable detailed logging of access attempts, both successful and unsuccessful, as well as changes to access control settings.
  • Regular Audits: Periodically audit access logs to identify unauthorized access attempts or patterns indicative of potential security issues.

6. Enforce Encryption for Data In Transit and At Rest

  • Encrypt Data in Transit: Use protocols like TLS to encrypt data being transferred to and from the DFS.
  • Encrypt Data at Rest: Ensure data stored on the DFS is encrypted using strong encryption standards to protect against unauthorized access even if physical security controls fail.

7. Educate Users and Administrators

  • Training: Provide regular training for users and administrators on the importance of access control, how to handle sensitive data, and recognizing potential security threats.
  • Best Practices: Distribute guidelines on creating strong passwords, recognizing phishing attempts, and safely sharing data.

References and Good Security Practices

  • Refer to Industry Standards: Use security frameworks and standards such as NIST's guidelines for access control or the ISO/IEC 27000 series to inform your access control policies.
  • OWASP Recommendations: For web-based access to the DFS, follow the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) recommendations for securing web applications and APIs.

By methodically implementing these steps, you can effectively enforce access control within a Distributed File System, significantly enhancing its security posture and protecting against unauthorized access or data breaches.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1022 - Restrict File and Directory Permissions

countermeasure.name: Implement rate limiting and traffic shaping to mitigate DoS attacks
countermeasure.desc:
Mitigating Denial of Service (DoS) attacks in a Distributed File System (DFS) is essential to maintain availability and ensure continuous access to data for legitimate users. Follow these steps to protect your DFS against DoS attacks:

1. Implement Redundancy

  • Distribute Data: Ensure data is replicated across multiple nodes and locations within your DFS. This not only provides fault tolerance but also disperses the load, making it harder for an attack to impact the entire system.
  • Load Balancing: Use load balancers to distribute incoming requests evenly across the nodes of your DFS. This helps prevent any single node from becoming a bottleneck under normal or attack conditions.

2. Configure Rate Limiting

  • Limit Requests: Implement rate limiting to control the number of requests a user can make to the DFS within a given timeframe. This helps prevent overloading the system with excessive requests.
  • Anomaly Detection: Automatically detect and block IP addresses or users that exceed predefined thresholds, signaling potentially malicious behavior.

3. Employ Traffic Analysis and Filtering

  • Analyze Traffic Patterns: Use network monitoring tools to analyze traffic patterns and identify anomalies indicative of a DoS attack, such as sudden spikes in traffic.
  • Filter Traffic: Deploy network firewalls and intrusion detection/prevention systems (IDS/IPS) to filter out malicious traffic based on known attack signatures or unusual activity patterns.

4. Use a Content Delivery Network (CDN)

  • Distribute Content: A CDN can cache static content from your DFS at geographically distributed nodes, reducing the load on the primary DFS infrastructure and improving resilience against DoS attacks.
  • Absorb Traffic: CDNs are designed to handle large volumes of web traffic and can absorb and mitigate large-scale DoS attacks.

5. Implement Application Layer Protection

  • Deploy WAF: Use a Web Application Firewall (WAF) to inspect and filter incoming HTTP/HTTPS traffic to web-based interfaces of your DFS. WAFs can mitigate application-layer DoS attacks by blocking malicious requests.
  • Secure APIs: If your DFS is accessed via APIs, ensure they are secured and rate-limited to prevent abuse.

6. Ensure Scalability

  • Auto-scaling: Utilize auto-scaling for your DFS infrastructure to automatically increase resources during demand spikes, which could be indicative of a DoS attack, to maintain service availability.

7. Prepare a Response Plan

  • Incident Response Plan: Develop and maintain an incident response plan specifically for DoS attacks. This plan should include procedures for identifying the attack, mitigating its effects, communicating with stakeholders, and restoring normal operations.
  • Regular Testing: Periodically test your response plan through drills and simulations to ensure effectiveness and readiness.

8. Engage with Upstream Providers

  • DDoS Protection Services: Work with your internet service provider (ISP) or consider specialized DDoS protection service providers that can offer additional layers of defense against large-scale DoS attacks.

References and Good Security Practices

  • Continuous Monitoring: Implement continuous monitoring of network and application performance to quickly detect and respond to potential DoS attacks.
  • Security Updates: Regularly update your DFS software, network security appliances, and any other critical infrastructure components to protect against known vulnerabilities that could be exploited in a DoS attack.

By adopting these measures, you can significantly enhance the resilience of your Distributed File System against DoS attacks, ensuring data availability and continuity of service for legitimate users.
