usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers overwhelm the file system to make it unavailable
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

In the context of a Distributed File System (DFS), a Denial of Service (DoS) attack aims to disrupt the normal operations of the system, rendering it unable to serve legitimate requests. This is achieved by overwhelming the file system with a flood of traffic or requests that consume its resources (such as bandwidth, disk space, or processing power), or by exploiting software vulnerabilities to cause the system to crash or become unresponsive. Unlike other attack types that seek unauthorized access or data exfiltration, the primary goal of a DoS attack is disruption of service.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: DoS attacks can be launched by a wide range of actors, including disgruntled employees, hacktivists seeking to make a political statement, competitors attempting to disrupt services, or cybercriminals looking to extort money by threatening or carrying out attacks.
  • Attack Vectors: Common vectors for DoS attacks against distributed file systems include:
    • Volume-based Attacks: Flooding the network with high volumes of data traffic to saturate bandwidth.
    • Protocol Attacks: Exploiting weaknesses in communication protocols to consume server resources or disrupt communications.
    • Application Layer Attacks: Targeting specific application functions or features to consume excessive resources and render services unavailable.
    • Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS): Coordinating attacks from multiple compromised systems (botnets) to amplify the attack's effectiveness.

Impacts

The impacts of DoS attacks on a Distributed File System include:

  • Service Disruption: Legitimate users are unable to access files or services, leading to downtime and potential loss of productivity or revenue.
  • System Damage: In extreme cases, the overwhelming traffic can cause hardware failures or corrupt data.
  • Reputational Damage: Frequent or severe disruptions can damage an organization's reputation, leading to loss of trust among users or customers.
  • Financial Costs: Responding to and mitigating the effects of DoS attacks can result in significant financial costs, including investment in mitigation technologies, increased operational costs, and potential legal liabilities.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the DFS's protocol to initiate a flood of malformed requests, consuming the system's processing resources and preventing legitimate file operations from being executed.
  • Scenario 2: A coordinated DDoS attack targets the DFS by commanding a botnet to send an overwhelming volume of traffic, saturating the network bandwidth and making the file system inaccessible to users.
  • Scenario 3: Attackers identify and exploit a specific feature of the file system's web management interface, sending repeated requests that cause the service to allocate excessive memory, eventually leading to service failure and system crash.

Mitigation strategies against DoS attacks in Distributed File Systems include implementing robust network security measures like traffic filtering, rate limiting, and anomaly detection systems to identify and mitigate suspicious traffic patterns. Additionally, maintaining up-to-date system patches, employing redundancy and failover mechanisms, and engaging in regular security assessments can help identify vulnerabilities before they can be exploited in an attack.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers exploit flaws in how access to data and features is restricted
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure Access Control in a Distributed File System (DFS) refers to deficiencies in the mechanisms that manage who or what can access or perform actions on the DFS. These systems, designed to store and manage data across multiple servers, rely heavily on access controls to ensure data integrity, confidentiality, and availability. Insecure access controls can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, data manipulation, and service disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents can range from external attackers, such as hackers looking to exploit vulnerabilities for access to sensitive data, to internal users (e.g., employees) who may unintentionally or maliciously gain access to data or functionalities not intended for their use. Attack vectors include:

  • Brute Force Attacks: Attempting to guess passwords or encryption keys.
  • Social Engineering: Tricking employees into granting access.
  • Exploiting Configuration Weaknesses: Taking advantage of misconfigured permissions or outdated software.
  • Privilege Escalation: Gaining elevated access by exploiting system vulnerabilities.

Impacts

The impacts of insecure access control in a DFS are profound, including:

  • Data Breaches: Unauthorized access to sensitive or proprietary information.
  • Data Loss or Corruption: Unauthorized actions leading to data being deleted, altered, or corrupted.
  • Service Disruption: Overloading the system with unauthorized requests, leading to denial of service.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaches resulting from insecure access control can lead to violations of regulatory requirements, resulting in fines and legal consequences.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: Misconfiguration Exploitation An attacker discovers a misconfigured DFS server that improperly exposes sensitive directories to the internet without adequate access controls. The attacker downloads sensitive data, including customer information, leading to a data breach.

Scenario 2: Privilege Escalation An employee with basic access to the DFS discovers a vulnerability that allows them to escalate their privileges. They gain administrative access, modify access controls, and grant themselves and others unauthorized access to restricted data.

Scenario 3: Password Spraying An attacker uses common passwords against multiple user accounts in the DFS, eventually gaining access to an account with permissions to view and alter sensitive files. This access is used to steal and ransom data.

Mitigation Strategies

To mitigate the risks associated with insecure access control in a Distributed File System, organizations should:

  • Implement Strong Access Control Policies: Define and enforce who has access to what data and actions within the DFS based on the principle of least privilege.
  • Regularly Review and Update Access Controls: Periodically review access rights and adjust them based on changing needs and roles within the organization.
  • Use Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Enhance security by requiring more than one method of authentication for user access.
  • Encrypt Sensitive Data: Protect data at rest and in transit to prevent unauthorized access and ensure data integrity.
  • Monitor and Audit Access: Regularly monitor access logs and conduct audits to detect unauthorized access attempts or misconfigurations promptly.
  • Educate Users: Train employees on the importance of secure access practices, including the use of strong passwords and recognizing social engineering attacks.

By addressing insecure access control comprehensively, organizations can significantly reduce the risk of unauthorized access and its associated impacts on a Distributed File System.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1556 - Modify Authentication Process||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1556.004 - Network Device Authentication

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers take advantage of unprotected dat
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data Exposure in a Distributed File System (DFS) refers to the unintended release or accessibility of sensitive information stored within the file system to unauthorized individuals or entities. Unlike a data breach, which is the result of a deliberate attack to steal information, data exposure often occurs due to misconfigurations, insufficient access controls, or errors in software development and deployment. This vulnerability can lead to the compromise of confidential, proprietary, or personal information, undermining the privacy and security of individuals and organizations alike.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Potential perpetrators exploiting data exposure vulnerabilities range from internal users with excessive permissions accidentally accessing or sharing sensitive data, to external attackers discovering and exploiting weaknesses in the file system's configuration or access controls.
  • Attack Vectors: Common vectors include:
    • Misconfigurations: Incorrect settings in the file system that leave sensitive data unprotected or publicly accessible.
    • Inadequate Access Controls: Failure to enforce the principle of least privilege, allowing users more access than necessary, which can lead to unauthorized data viewing or modification.
    • Software Vulnerabilities: Flaws in the file system software that can be exploited to bypass security measures and access restricted data.
    • Human Error: Mistakes made by users or administrators, such as accidentally making private data public or sharing sensitive files with the wrong parties.

Impacts

The impacts of data exposure in a Distributed File System include:

  • Privacy Violation: Exposure of personal or sensitive data can result in privacy breaches, affecting individuals' rights and freedoms.
  • Intellectual Property Theft: Unauthorized access to proprietary information can lead to intellectual property theft, undermining competitive advantages.
  • Compliance Violations: Data exposure incidents can lead to violations of regulatory requirements (such as GDPR, HIPAA), resulting in fines and legal action.
  • Reputational Damage: The loss of trust from customers, partners, and the public due to perceived negligence can have long-lasting effects on an organization's reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An administrator inadvertently configures a storage bucket within the DFS to be publicly accessible, leading to the exposure of sensitive documents containing personal data of clients.
  • Scenario 2: An external attacker exploits a vulnerability in the DFS's web interface, gaining unauthorized read access to files that contain confidential business strategies and customer information.
  • Scenario 3: A user with more access rights than necessary mistakenly moves sensitive files to a shared folder accessible by a broader group within the organization, leading to unintended data exposure.

Mitigation strategies against data exposure in Distributed File Systems include:

  • Regular Audits and Reviews: Conducting regular audits of configurations and access controls to ensure that data is protected according to organizational policies and regulatory requirements.
  • Access Control Policies: Implementing strict access control policies based on the principle of least privilege, ensuring that users have access only to the data necessary for their role.
  • Encryption: Encrypting data at rest and in transit to protect sensitive information, making it unreadable to unauthorized users even if they gain access.
  • User Training: Educating users and administrators about the risks of data exposure and best practices for handling sensitive information securely.
  • Automated Tools: Utilizing automated tools to detect misconfigurations or unauthorized access patterns in real time, allowing for quick remediation of potential vulnerabilities.

threat.name: Attackers exploit incorrect or incomplete setup of the file system
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Misconfiguration in a Distributed File System (DFS) encompasses incorrect setup or lack of appropriate security settings within the system's software or hardware components. Given the complexity and scalability of DFS, misconfigurations can occur at various levels, including network settings, file permissions, authentication mechanisms, and encryption protocols. Such vulnerabilities make the system an easy target for attackers, leading to unauthorized access, data leakage, or denial-of-service attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents exploiting misconfigurations can range from external attackers to insider threats. Attack vectors include:

  • Scanning for Vulnerabilities: Attackers use automated tools to scan networks and systems for common misconfigurations.
  • Exploiting Default Settings: Default usernames, passwords, or settings that are not secured provide easy entry points.
  • Bypassing Incomplete Security Controls: Inadequately configured firewalls, encryption settings, or access controls can be bypassed.
  • Manipulating Misconfigured Permissions: Incorrect file or directory permissions can allow unauthorized reading, modification, or deletion of data.

Impacts

The impacts of misconfiguration in a DFS can be severe, including:

  • Data Breaches: Exposing sensitive information to unauthorized parties.
  • Service Disruption: Overloaded services or disabled security features can lead to downtime.
  • Legal and Compliance Issues: Failure to protect data can result in non-compliance with regulations, leading to fines and reputational damage.
  • Resource Hijacking: Misconfigured systems may be hijacked for malicious purposes, such as launching attacks on other systems.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: Default Credentials An attacker discovers a DFS node that is still using default login credentials, allowing them to gain full administrative access. They exploit this access to steal sensitive data stored in the DFS.

Scenario 2: Open Network Ports Through scanning, an attacker finds open network ports on a DFS node that should have been closed or restricted. They use these open ports to inject malicious code into the system, compromising the integrity of the data stored across the DFS.

Scenario 3: Inadequate Encryption Settings A DFS is configured to use weak encryption for data transmission. An eavesdropper intercepts the data in transit, decrypting sensitive information and leading to a data breach.

Mitigation Strategies

To prevent and mitigate the risks associated with misconfiguration in a Distributed File System, consider the following strategies:

  • Regular Configuration Reviews: Conduct periodic audits of the DFS configurations and compare them against industry best practices and compliance requirements.
  • Use Configuration Management Tools: Implement tools that automate the configuration process to ensure consistency and reduce human error.
  • Harden Security Settings: Apply security hardening guidelines to remove unnecessary services, close unused ports, and enforce strong authentication and encryption practices.
  • Implement Least Privilege Principle: Ensure that users and services have only the minimum levels of access necessary for their roles.
  • Continuous Monitoring: Deploy monitoring solutions to detect changes in configurations and potentially unauthorized activities in real-time.
  • Security Training: Educate staff about the importance of secure configurations, common pitfalls, and best practices for maintaining security.

By proactively addressing misconfiguration issues, organizations can significantly enhance the security and resilience of their Distributed File System against a wide array of threats.

component.name: Kinesis Firehose (Data Ingestion)
component.desc: Kinesis Firehose for data ingestion.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

countermeasure.name: Configure proper data backup and recovery mechanisms for Firehose delivery streams
countermeasure.desc:
Objective: Ensure data resiliency, availability, and disaster recovery for Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose delivery streams by configuring appropriate data backup and recovery mechanisms.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Source Record Backup:

  • Configure your Firehose delivery streams to back up all source data to an Amazon S3 bucket. This backup can be for all data or only failed data, depending on your needs. For destinations other than Amazon S3 and Amazon Redshift, this setting indicates if you want to back up all source data or failed data only (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Configure S3 Backup Settings:

  • S3 Bucket: Choose or create an S3 bucket where the backup data will be stored.
  • S3 Prefix: Specify a prefix for the S3 bucket to organize the backup files logically.
  • Error Output Prefix: Define a prefix for storing failed records, making it easier to identify and manage error data (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Set Buffering Hints:

  • Adjust the buffering size (1-128 MiB) and buffering interval (60-900 seconds) to optimize data delivery and backup performance. These settings help balance the trade-off between latency and throughput, ensuring efficient data processing and storage (AWS Documentation).

Enable Compression and Encryption:

  • Compression: Use compression methods such as GZIP, Snappy, or Zip to reduce storage costs and improve transfer speeds. Note that not all compression methods are compatible with all destinations (e.g., Snappy is not available for Amazon Redshift) (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).
  • Encryption: Implement server-side encryption using AWS Key Management Service (SSE-KMS) to protect your data. You can choose to use the default S3 encryption or a customer-managed key for additional security (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Monitor and Log Errors:

  • Enable error logging in CloudWatch to capture detailed logs of any data delivery or processing errors. This practice is crucial for troubleshooting and ensuring data integrity during recovery processes (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Set Up Disaster Recovery:

  • Utilize the multi-AZ (Availability Zone) support and automatic migration features of AWS to ensure high availability and disaster recovery. Firehose automatically handles host degradations and AZ availability issues, ensuring continuous data flow without data loss (AWS Documentation).

Best Practices:

  • Regularly review and test your backup and recovery configurations to ensure they meet your organizational needs.
  • Implement IAM roles with the least privilege principle to manage access to your Firehose streams and S3 buckets, enhancing security.
  • Periodically audit your S3 bucket contents and lifecycle policies to manage storage costs and maintain data hygiene.

For more detailed guidance, refer to the AWS Kinesis Data Firehose Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Enable server-side encryption using AWS KMS for data stored in Firehose delivery streams
countermeasure.desc:
Objective: Secure data in transit and at rest within Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose delivery streams by enabling server-side encryption (SSE) using AWS Key Management Service (KMS).

Implementation Steps:

Create an AWS KMS Key:

  • If you do not already have a KMS key, create one through the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs. This key will be used to encrypt data in your Firehose delivery streams.
  • To create a KMS key, navigate to the KMS section in the AWS Management Console, choose Create Key, and follow the prompts to define key policies and permissions (AWS Documentation).

Configure Encryption in Firehose Delivery Stream:

  • When creating or updating a Firehose delivery stream, configure server-side encryption settings to use the KMS key.
  • During the creation process, in the Configure Settings step, under Advanced Settings, enable server-side encryption and select your KMS key from the list (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Specify the KMS Key in the Firehose Console:

  • In the Firehose console, go to the Create Delivery Stream wizard.
  • In the Set Destination section, find the encryption settings.
  • Enable encryption and choose the KMS key you created from the dropdown menu.
  • Save and continue with the setup (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Update Existing Streams with Encryption:

  • To enable encryption for existing delivery streams, use the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs.
  • In the Firehose console, select the delivery stream you wish to update, choose Edit, navigate to the encryption settings, and select your KMS key (AWS Documentation).

Verify Permissions:

  • Ensure that the Firehose delivery stream has the necessary IAM permissions to use the KMS key.
  • The IAM role associated with the Firehose stream must have the kms:Encrypt and kms:Decrypt permissions for the specified KMS key. This can be configured in the IAM policy associated with the role (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Monitor Encryption Metrics:

  • Use Amazon CloudWatch to monitor metrics related to encryption.
  • Track logs and metrics for any encryption-related errors or warnings to ensure continuous data protection (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Best Practices:

  • Regularly rotate your KMS keys to enhance security.
  • Apply least privilege principles when configuring IAM policies to restrict access to KMS keys.
  • Enable CloudTrail logging for all KMS key usage to maintain an audit trail of all encryption and decryption operations.

For more detailed guidance, refer to the AWS Kinesis Data Firehose Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Implement fine-grained access control to restrict permissions to specific Firehose actions using IAM policies
countermeasure.desc:
Objective: Enhance security by restricting access to specific Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose actions through fine-grained IAM policies.

Implementation Steps:

Identify Required Permissions:

  • Determine the specific actions that users and services need to perform on the Firehose delivery streams. Common actions include firehose:CreateDeliveryStream, firehose:PutRecord, firehose:PutRecordBatch, and firehose:DeleteDeliveryStream.
  • Refer to the AWS Kinesis Data Firehose API documentation for a complete list of actions and their descriptions (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Create Custom IAM Policies:

  • Define custom IAM policies that grant only the necessary permissions. Use the principle of least privilege to ensure that users and roles have only the permissions they need to perform their tasks.

Attach Policies to Users or Roles:

  • Attach the custom IAM policies to the appropriate users, groups, or roles. This ensures that only authorized entities can perform the specified actions on your Firehose delivery streams.
  • Example command to attach a policy to a role using AWS CLI:

aws iam attach-role-policy --role-name YourRoleName --policy-arn arn:aws:iam::aws:policy/YourCustomPolicy

Test the IAM Policies:

  • After creating and attaching the policies, test them to ensure they work as intended. Use AWS IAM Access Analyzer or AWS IAM Policy Simulator to validate that the policies restrict access appropriately.
  • Make adjustments as necessary based on the testing results to tighten or loosen permissions (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Monitor and Audit IAM Activities:

  • Enable AWS CloudTrail to log and monitor all IAM activities, including policy changes and access to Firehose delivery streams. This helps in auditing and identifying any unauthorized access attempts.
  • Set up AWS CloudWatch Alarms to notify administrators of any suspicious activity or policy changes (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Review and Update Policies Regularly:

  • Regularly review and update IAM policies to adapt to changes in user roles, job functions, and security requirements. Ensure that the policies remain aligned with the principle of least privilege.
  • Conduct periodic access reviews and audits to ensure compliance with organizational security standards and best practices (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

For more detailed guidance, refer to the AWS Kinesis Data Firehose Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Regularly validate Firehose delivery stream configurations to meet security and operational requirements
countermeasure.desc:
Objective: Ensure that Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose delivery streams continuously comply with security policies and operational requirements through regular validation and auditing.

Implementation Steps:

Set Up Initial Configuration Review:

  • When creating a new Firehose delivery stream, document the initial configurations including data transformation settings, encryption methods, buffer sizes, and error logging settings. This serves as a baseline for future reviews (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Schedule Regular Reviews:

  • Establish a regular review cycle (e.g., monthly, quarterly) to validate Firehose configurations. This helps ensure that the delivery streams meet evolving security policies and operational requirements.

Automate Configuration Audits:

  • Use AWS Config to continuously monitor and record configurations of Firehose delivery streams. Set up AWS Config Rules to evaluate the compliance of these configurations with your organizational policies.
  • AWS Config can trigger AWS Lambda functions to remediate non-compliant resources automatically (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Monitor Key Metrics and Logs:

  • Use Amazon CloudWatch to monitor key metrics such as delivery failures, data ingestion rates, and buffer usage. Set up CloudWatch Alarms to notify administrators of any anomalies.
  • Enable detailed logging through Amazon CloudWatch Logs for deeper insights into the operation of Firehose delivery streams, including data transformation errors and delivery failures (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Conduct Manual Reviews:

  • Regularly perform manual reviews of Firehose configurations using the AWS Management Console or AWS CLI. Verify that settings such as buffer sizes, retry intervals, and compression methods align with current operational requirements and best practices (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).
  • Example AWS CLI command to describe a delivery stream:

aws firehose describe-delivery-stream --delivery-stream-name your-stream-name

Validate Security Configurations:

  • Ensure that encryption is enabled for all Firehose delivery streams, using AWS Key Management Service (KMS) for server-side encryption.
  • Verify that IAM policies attached to Firehose roles are following the principle of least privilege. Regularly audit IAM roles and policies to ensure they have the necessary permissions without over-provisioning (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).

Update Documentation and Training:

  • Maintain up-to-date documentation of Firehose configurations and validation processes. Ensure that the operations team is trained on the latest security practices and operational procedures for managing Firehose delivery streams.

Best Practices:

  • Use tagging to categorize and manage Firehose delivery streams based on their purpose, sensitivity, and compliance requirements.
  • Regularly review and update lifecycle policies for S3 buckets storing Firehose backup data to manage storage costs and compliance with data retention policies (AWS Documentation) (AWS Documentation).
  • Implement versioning in S3 buckets to protect against accidental deletions or overwrites of backup data.

For more detailed guidance, refer to the AWS Kinesis Data Firehose Developer Guide.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Improper access controls can result in unauthorized users accessing, modifying, or deleting Kinesis Data Firehose resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access controls can result in unauthorized users accessing, modifying, or deleting Kinesis Data Firehose resources. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, compromised user accounts, or external attackers who exploit weak permission settings or misconfigurations in access control policies. 
Impacts
The primary impacts of this threat include data breaches, data loss or corruption, and unauthorized use of resources, which could compromise data integrity, confidentiality, and availability. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gaining access to an inadequately protected AWS IAM role could modify Firehose delivery streams, redirecting data to an unauthorized endpoint, or could delete data streams, causing significant data loss and service disruption.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data exposure due to inadequate encryption measures during transit or at rest
threat.desc:
General threat description
Data exposure due to inadequate encryption measures during transit or at rest.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cyber attackers can intercept data in transit through man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks or exploit unencrypted storage locations 
Impacts
Unauthorized data access, data breaches, loss of confidentiality, and potential regulatory fines 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker intercepts data being sent to AWS Kinesis Data Firehose through a MITM attack, or gains access to unencrypted data stored within the system, thus compromising sensitive information

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

threat.name: Misconfiguration of Firehose resources can lead to vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfiguration of Firehose resources can lead to vulnerabilities. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include insider threats, such as employees misconfiguring resources, or external attackers exploiting misconfigured Firehose resources. Attack vectors can involve leveraging weaknesses in configuration settings or gaining unauthorized access to the system. 
Impacts
The impacts can span data breaches, unauthorized data access, data loss, and regulatory non-compliance, potentially leading to significant financial and reputational damage. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An employee accidentally misconfigures the Firehose delivery stream to allow public access, which could be exploited by an attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data. Another scenario could involve incorrect IAM policies that give unauthorized users access to Kinesis streams, resulting in data leaks or data manipulation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Improper data backup and recovery configurations can lead to data loss
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper data backup and recovery configurations can lead to data loss. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include misconfigured settings, lack of adequate backup procedures, or neglecting to test recovery plans. Attack vectors encompass accidental deletion, data corruption, and unplanned outages. 
Impacts
The primary impact is potential data loss, which can result in operational downtime, financial losses, and damage to reputation. Additionally, it can affect compliance with data retention policies and regulations. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An example scenario might involve an AWS Kinesis Data Firehose stream where backups are not regularly scheduled. In the event of an accidental deletion or corruption of the data stream, the recovery process fails due to improperly configured recovery settings, resulting in permanent data loss. Another scenario could involve a backup configuration that does not include the latest changes, leading to data discrepancies upon restoration.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

weakness.name: CWE-1004
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1004: Sensitive Cookie Without 'HttpOnly' Flag The product uses a cookie to store sensitive information, but the cookie is not marked with the HttpOnly flag. The HttpOnly flag directs compatible browsers to prevent client-side script from accessing cookies. Including the HttpOnly flag in the Set-Cookie HTTP response header helps mitigate the risk associated with Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) where an attacker's script code might attempt to read the contents of a cookie and exfiltrate information obtained. When set, browsers that support the flag will not reveal the contents of the cookie to a third party via client-side script executed via XSS.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-539
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-539: Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information The web application uses persistent cookies, but the cookies contain sensitive information. Cookies are small bits of data that are sent by the web application but stored locally in the browser. This lets the application use the cookie to pass information between pages and store variable information. The web application controls what information is stored in a cookie and how it is used. Typical types of information stored in cookies are session identifiers, personalization and customization information, and in rare cases even usernames to enable automated logins. There are two different types of cookies: session cookies and persistent cookies. Session cookies just live in the browser's memory and are not stored anywhere, but persistent cookies are stored on the browser's hard drive. This can cause security and privacy issues depending on the information stored in the cookie and how it is accessed.

weakness.name: CWE-663
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-663: Use of a Non-reentrant Function in a Concurrent Context The product calls a non-reentrant function in a concurrent context in which a competing code sequence (e.g. thread or signal handler) may have an opportunity to call the same function or otherwise influence its state.

countermeasure.name: Conduct frequent configuration reviews
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly review system and server configurations to ensure that security settings are properly implemented and sensitive data is not exposed. Conducting configuration reviews helps identify misconfigurations, weak access controls, and other vulnerabilities that could lead to unauthorized access or data leakage.

Implementation Steps:

Define Configuration Review Scope:

  • Include critical configurations such as access controls, encryption settings, user permissions, and network configurations in the review.
  • Ensure compliance with security best practices and regulatory requirements (e.g., GDPR, PCI DSS).

Review Access Controls:

  • Verify that only authorized users have access to sensitive data and critical systems.
  • Ensure that default credentials and unnecessary accounts are removed or disabled.

Check Data Protection Settings:

  • Ensure that sensitive data is encrypted both in transit (using TLS) and at rest (using strong encryption algorithms like AES).
  • Review file permissions to ensure that sensitive files are not accessible to unauthorized users.

Examine Security Policies and Rules:

  • Regularly audit security policies, firewall rules, and network configurations to ensure they are up to date and provide the necessary protection.
  • Verify that logging and monitoring systems are correctly configured to detect any suspicious activity.

Document and Act on Findings:

  • Document all findings from the configuration reviews and prioritize actions to address non-compliant configurations or identified vulnerabilities.
  • Implement changes and re-test configurations to ensure they align with security standards.

Schedule Regular Reviews:

  • Perform configuration reviews quarterly or after significant changes to the environment (e.g., updates, new deployments).
  • Use automated tools to assist with the review process, making it more efficient and thorough.

By conducting frequent configuration reviews, organizations can ensure that security settings are correct, minimizing the risk of exposure and ensuring that sensitive data remains protected.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-53: Security and Privacy Controls

countermeasure.name: Enforce role-based access controls and multi-factor authentication
countermeasure.desc:
Implement role-based access controls (RBAC), multi-factor authentication (MFA), and the principle of least privilege to minimize unauthorized access to internal systems and resources. By ensuring that only authorized personnel have access to necessary data and systems, these measures reduce the risk of accidental or intentional misuse of sensitive information and limit exposure to attacks.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

  • Define roles within your organization and assign permissions based on job responsibilities. Ensure that each user has access only to the resources necessary for their role.
  • Regularly review and update roles to reflect any changes in job functions or responsibilities.

Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):

  • Require MFA for all users accessing critical systems or sensitive data. This ensures that even if credentials are compromised, unauthorized access is still prevented.
  • Use authentication methods like mobile apps, hardware tokens, or biometrics alongside passwords.

Enforce the Principle of Least Privilege:

  • Ensure that users, systems, and applications have the minimum level of access required to perform their tasks.
  • Review and adjust access levels periodically to ensure they remain aligned with users' current roles.

Audit and Review Access Logs:

  • Regularly audit access logs to ensure that access controls are being properly enforced and that no unauthorized access has occurred.
  • Implement alerts to notify administrators of suspicious or anomalous access attempts.

Educate and Train Users:

  • Provide ongoing training to users on secure access practices, including how to use MFA and why least privilege is important.
  • Educate users about the risks of privilege escalation and how to securely manage their credentials.

By enforcing these access control measures, developers and DevOps engineers can reduce the risk of unauthorized access and ensure that only the appropriate personnel can access sensitive resources.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-53: Access Control

countermeasure.name: Ensure server software is up-to-date with security patches
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly update all server software, including operating systems and applications, with the latest security patches. Keeping software up-to-date reduces the risk of exploitation due to known vulnerabilities. Establish a patch management process to ensure timely updates and minimize exposure to security threats.

Implementation Steps:

Establish Patch Management Process:

  • Develop a formal patch management policy that includes patch assessment, approval, and deployment procedures.
  • Prioritize patches based on their severity and impact on server security.

Automate Patching for Critical Systems:

  • Use automation tools to deploy critical patches as soon as they are available to minimize the window of vulnerability.
  • Ensure that automatic updates are enabled for operating systems and essential applications.

Test Patches in a Staging Environment:

  • Before applying patches to production systems, test them in a staging environment to ensure they do not cause system instability or conflicts with other software.

Regularly Review Security Bulletins:

  • Subscribe to security mailing lists, such as those from software vendors and organizations like CVE or NIST, to stay informed about the latest vulnerabilities and patches.
  • Monitor patch release cycles for both operating systems and third-party applications to apply patches promptly.

Track Patch Compliance:

  • Implement a monitoring system to track which systems have received the latest patches and generate compliance reports.
  • Perform regular audits to ensure that all critical systems are patched according to the defined policy.

Maintain Backup Before Applying Patches:

  • Ensure that a backup of the server and critical data is taken before applying patches, to facilitate recovery in case of issues.

By ensuring that all server software is regularly updated with the latest security patches, organizations can significantly reduce their exposure to security vulnerabilities.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-40: Guide to Enterprise Patch Management Technologies

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)

countermeasure.name: Install and configure antivirus and IDS/IPS systems
countermeasure.desc:
Install and maintain antivirus software and intrusion detection/prevention systems (IDS/IPS) on internal servers to monitor and protect against malware attacks. These systems detect, prevent, and alert on malicious activities by analyzing server traffic and system behavior. Regularly update antivirus signatures and IDS/IPS rules to enhance their effectiveness in identifying new threats. Ensure that alerts are reviewed promptly to take immediate action against potential malware infections.

Implementation Steps:

Install Antivirus Software:

  • Deploy antivirus software on all internal servers to scan for and eliminate known malware.
  • Ensure that automatic updates for antivirus definitions are enabled to keep the system up-to-date.

Configure IDS/IPS:

  • Set up intrusion detection/prevention systems to monitor network traffic and server behavior for suspicious activities.
  • Regularly update IDS/IPS signatures and detection rules to stay ahead of emerging threats.

Configure Alerting and Logging:

  • Set up alerts for any detected malware or suspicious activities to notify system administrators immediately.
  • Ensure that detailed logs are maintained for all detected events to allow for post-incident analysis and troubleshooting.

Regular Updates and Patching:

  • Schedule routine updates for both antivirus and IDS/IPS software to ensure vulnerabilities are patched and signatures are up to date.
  • Perform periodic reviews of the effectiveness of the systems in place.

Test Effectiveness:

  • Run periodic tests and simulations to ensure that antivirus and IDS/IPS systems are identifying threats effectively and responding in real time.

By implementing antivirus and IDS/IPS systems, developers and DevOps engineers can minimize the risk of malware infections and ensure continuous monitoring of the internal server environment.

References:

  • Basic Intrusion Prevention System

countermeasure.name: Restrict physical access with security measures
countermeasure.desc:
Implement strict physical security measures to restrict unauthorized access to servers and sensitive areas. Use biometric authentication, CCTV surveillance, and secure facility access policies to control who can access critical systems. Ensure that only authorized personnel can enter data centers or server rooms, reducing the risk of tampering, theft, or physical damage to the servers.

Implementation Steps:

Install Biometric Authentication:

  • Implement biometric systems (e.g., fingerprint or retina scans) to control access to sensitive areas like server rooms and data centers.
  • Ensure biometric systems are integrated with facility access control systems to track and log access attempts.

Set Up CCTV Surveillance:

  • Deploy CCTV cameras at key entry points and throughout sensitive areas to monitor and record access.
  • Store video footage securely and ensure it is reviewed periodically for security threats or breaches.

Establish Secure Access Policies:

  • Create access control policies that define who is authorized to enter critical areas and under what conditions.
  • Ensure that all access is logged and periodically audited to identify unauthorized attempts.

Implement Security Personnel and Alarms:

  • Use security guards and alarm systems to monitor facility access, ensuring unauthorized individuals are immediately detected.
  • Integrate alarm systems with access logs to trigger alerts if unauthorized access is attempted.

Enforce Role-Based Physical Access:

  • Limit access to the most sensitive areas to personnel with a need-to-know basis, using role-based access controls for physical access.

By applying physical security measures, organizations can prevent unauthorized physical access to critical infrastructure, reducing the risk of tampering, theft, or other malicious activities.

References:

  • Physical and Environmental Security

countermeasure.name: Use DDoS protection services and traffic filtering
countermeasure.desc:
Implement DDoS protection services, rate limiting, and traffic filtering to defend against Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. These measures help mitigate the impact of overwhelming traffic on the internal server by filtering malicious traffic, controlling the rate of incoming requests, and redirecting suspicious traffic to secure environments for analysis. Regularly update and configure these services to adapt to evolving attack techniques.

Implementation Steps:

Enable DDoS Protection Services:

  • Use cloud-based DDoS protection services, such as AWS Shield, Azure DDoS Protection, or Google Cloud Armor, to detect and mitigate large-scale attacks.
  • Configure the service to automatically detect and mitigate traffic spikes that may indicate a DDoS attack.

Implement Rate Limiting:

  • Set up rate limiting to restrict the number of requests that can be made to the server within a specific time frame, preventing an overload of the servers resources.
  • Use API gateways or web application firewalls (WAF) to enforce rate limits for critical services.

Configure Traffic Filtering:

  • Implement traffic filtering mechanisms to block malicious traffic and allow only legitimate requests from trusted sources.
  • Use tools like Web Application Firewalls (WAF) or reverse proxies to filter out harmful traffic, such as SQL injection attempts or bot traffic.

Monitor Traffic for Anomalies:

  • Set up real-time traffic monitoring to detect anomalies such as sudden spikes in traffic or unusual request patterns.
  • Use centralized logging and alerting systems to notify security teams of potential DDoS attacks.

Regularly Test and Update Protection Mechanisms:

  • Regularly perform stress tests to assess the effectiveness of DDoS protection services and traffic filtering configurations.
  • Keep DDoS protection systems updated with the latest detection rules and algorithms to defend against new attack vectors.

By implementing DDoS protection services, rate limiting, and traffic filtering, developers and DevOps engineers can significantly reduce the risk and impact of DDoS attacks, ensuring better availability and stability of internal services.

References:

  • Denial of Service Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Use encryption protocols for data in transit and data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
Use strong encryption protocols such as TLS (Transport Layer Security) for data in transit and ensure that data at rest is encrypted with secure algorithms like AES (Advanced Encryption Standard). Encryption protects sensitive information from unauthorized access, both during transmission over the network and when stored on servers. Regularly review encryption configurations and update protocols to ensure they comply with the latest security standards and prevent vulnerabilities.

Implementation Steps:

Enable TLS for Data in Transit:

  • Configure all server communication (e.g., HTTP, API calls) to use TLS 1.2 or higher.
  • Ensure certificates are valid, up to date, and issued by trusted certificate authorities (CAs).
  • Enforce strong ciphers and disable outdated versions (e.g., SSL, TLS 1.0/1.1) to ensure secure communication.

Encrypt Data at Rest:

  • Use strong encryption algorithms (e.g., AES-256) to encrypt sensitive data stored on the server, including databases, file systems, and backups.
  • Store encryption keys in a secure key management system (KMS) to prevent unauthorized access.

Configure Key Management:

  • Implement a secure process for key generation, storage, and rotation.
  • Ensure that encryption keys are rotated periodically and are not hardcoded in the application code.

Monitor and Audit Encryption Configurations:

  • Regularly audit encryption settings to ensure compliance with industry standards and organizational policies.
  • Use automated tools to monitor encryption protocols and identify any weaknesses or misconfigurations.

Stay Updated with Encryption Standards:

  • Regularly review and update encryption methods and algorithms to adhere to the latest security guidelines and best practices.
  • Ensure that encryption methods are aligned with regulatory requirements, such as GDPR or PCI DSS.

By applying encryption for both data in transit and data at rest, developers and DevOps engineers can protect sensitive information and reduce the risk of unauthorized access.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-53: Security and Privacy Controls

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers execute DoS/DDoS attacks to disrupt services
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

DoS/DDoS attacks aim to overwhelm a servers resources, making it unavailable for legitimate users, disrupting critical services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers using botnets or other methods to flood the server.
  • Internal Attackers: Malicious employees or compromised internal devices initiating attacks.
  • Vectors: Botnets, SYN floods, UDP floods, and amplification attacks.

Impacts

  • Downtime: The server becomes unavailable, halting business operations.
  • Resource Exhaustion: Depletion of server resources leading to slowdowns or crashes.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Botnet DDoS: Thousands of compromised devices flood the server with traffic, causing overload.
  • Application Layer Attack: Attackers target web services with requests to consume server resources.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers exploit vulnerabilities in the system
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers exploit unpatched vulnerabilities in the system to gain unauthorized access, execute malicious actions, or disrupt services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Cybercriminals scanning for and exploiting vulnerabilities in public-facing applications.
  • Internal Attackers: Insiders using known flaws to access sensitive systems or data.
  • Vectors: Unpatched software, misconfigurations, or insecure code in the application.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers gain control over sensitive data or systems.
  • System Compromise: Attackers can install malware, steal information, or disable services.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • SQL Injection: Exploiting a flaw in the server's database handling to execute malicious SQL commands.
  • Privilege Escalation: Using an unpatched vulnerability to gain higher privileges and control the server.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers try to gain unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers attempt to bypass authentication mechanisms to gain unauthorized access to the internal server, potentially compromising sensitive data or systems.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers attempting to exploit weak authentication mechanisms or stolen credentials.
  • Internal Attackers: Employees or contractors attempting to access restricted systems without proper authorization.
  • Vectors: Brute-force attacks, stolen credentials, and social engineering.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized System Access: Attackers gain access to sensitive systems or data.
  • Data Loss or Theft: Once inside, attackers can steal or alter critical data.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Brute-Force Attack: Attackers repeatedly attempt to guess passwords to gain access to the server.
  • Phishing Attack: Attackers trick legitimate users into revealing their credentials to access the system.

threat.name: Attackers cause information leakage through misconfigurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Misconfigurations in the system can lead to unintentional exposure of sensitive information to unauthorized parties.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting publicly accessible misconfigurations to gain sensitive data.
  • Internal Attackers: Insiders taking advantage of poor configuration practices.
  • Vectors: Misconfigured file permissions, open ports, or exposed services.

Impacts

  • Exposure of Sensitive Data: Confidential information is unintentionally exposed to unauthorized users.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaching data protection regulations due to improperly configured access controls.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Publicly Accessible Database: A misconfigured database allows unauthorized users to access sensitive records.
  • Misconfigured Cloud Storage: Insecure cloud storage settings lead to exposure of files or credentials.

threat.name: Attackers attempt to steal sensitive data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers target sensitive data stored on the server, attempting to steal or exfiltrate it for malicious purposes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers attempting to breach the server remotely to access confidential information.
  • Internal Attackers: Employees or contractors misusing their access to steal data.
  • Vectors: Exploiting vulnerabilities, phishing, or improper access controls.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Sensitive information such as customer data or proprietary information is exposed or stolen.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust from customers and partners due to the breach.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Phishing Attack: Attackers trick employees into revealing login credentials, granting access to sensitive data.
  • Data Exfiltration: Exploiting vulnerabilities to copy or transfer sensitive files to an external server.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1602 - Data from Configuration Repository

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers gain physical unauthorized access to the server
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers gain physical access to the server hardware, potentially allowing them to tamper with, steal, or damage the system and its data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Intruders attempting to bypass physical security to gain direct access to the server.
  • Internal Attackers: Employees or contractors misusing access privileges to physically compromise the server.
  • Vectors: Breaking into data centers, stealing server hardware, or gaining access to secure facilities.

Impacts

  • Data Theft: Physical access can lead to direct theft of sensitive data or hardware.
  • System Tampering: Attackers can alter system configurations or install malware, compromising server integrity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Data Center Break-In: Attackers infiltrate the data center and steal a server containing sensitive information.
  • Unauthorized Server Access: An employee with physical access installs malicious software on a server, bypassing network defenses.

threat.name: Attackers deploy malware to compromise the system
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers introduce malicious software (malware) into the system to exploit vulnerabilities, gain control, or cause damage.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Cybercriminals deploying malware through phishing emails, malicious downloads, or remote exploitation.
  • Internal Attackers: Insiders introducing malware to disrupt operations or steal data.
  • Vectors: Phishing, drive-by downloads, or exploiting software vulnerabilities.

Impacts

  • System Compromise: Malware can allow attackers to control the system, steal data, or spread across the network.
  • Data Corruption: Malware may corrupt or delete critical data, disrupting business operations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Phishing Email with Ransomware: Attackers send a malicious email attachment that installs ransomware upon opening.
  • Exploiting Unpatched Software: Attackers exploit an unpatched vulnerability to install a backdoor Trojan.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-541
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-541: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in an Include File If an include file source is accessible, the file can contain usernames and passwords, as well as sensitive information pertaining to the application and system.

countermeasure.name: Disable direct internet and root access for notebook
countermeasure.desc:
Disable direct internet access and root access for AWS SageMaker notebook instances to ensure secure and restricted access.

  1. Disable Direct Internet Access:
    • Set DirectInternetAccess to Disabled when creating or updating notebook instances.
  2. Disable Root Access:
    • Configure IAM policies or lifecycle configurations to restrict root access.
  3. Enable VPC-Only Mode:
    • Specify VPC subnets and security groups to route all traffic through your VPC.

countermeasure.name: Enable inter-container traffic encryption for distributed training jobs
countermeasure.desc:
Enable inter-container traffic encryption for distributed training jobs in AWS SageMaker to protect data during transfer between containers.

Enable Traffic Encryption:

  • Set the InterContainerTrafficEncryption parameter to True when creating or updating distributed training jobs. This ensures that all data transferred between containers is encrypted.

Verify Encryption Configuration:

  • Ensure that all containers in the distributed training job are configured to support encrypted communication.
  • Regularly review and audit the encryption settings to maintain compliance and security standards.

countermeasure.name: Enable network isolation for training jobs
countermeasure.desc:
Configure network isolation (VPC) for SageMaker training jobs to ensure containers cannot access the internet or other network resources without permission.

Enable Network Isolation:

  • Set the EnableNetworkIsolation parameter to True when creating or updating training jobs. This prevents containers from accessing the internet and other network resources.

Specify VPC Configuration:

  • Define VPC subnets and security groups to control network access for the training jobs.
  • Ensure the security groups are configured to allow only necessary inbound and outbound traffic.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Uncontrolled notebook instance access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Uncontrolled notebook instance access refers to improperly configured SageMaker notebook instances that allow unrestricted access, leading to security risks such as unauthorized data access and misuse of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • Malicious insiders
    • External attackers
    • Negligent users
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Enabled direct internet access
    • Allowed root access
    • Misconfigured security groups and ACLs
    • Exploitation of software vulnerabilities

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized access to sensitive data
  • Integrity: Data and model tampering
  • Availability: Service disruption or resource misuse
  • Reputation: Damage from data breaches

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unrestricted Internet Access:
    • An attacker exploits software vulnerabilities on a notebook instance with internet access, exfiltrating sensitive data.
  2. Root Access Misuse:
    • A user with root access installs malicious software, compromising the notebook instance.
  3. Misconfigured Network Controls:
    • An attacker gains access through open ports on a misconfigured instance, stealing and manipulating data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inadequate network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate network isolation occurs when Amazon SageMaker resources, such as training jobs, endpoints, or notebook instances, are not properly segregated within a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). This can lead to unauthorized access, data leakage, and potential security breaches, as these resources might be accessible from untrusted networks or the internet.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • External attackers (hackers)
    • Malicious insiders
    • Negligent users
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Lack of VPC configuration for SageMaker resources
    • Misconfigured VPC security groups and network ACLs
    • Public IP addresses assigned to instances
    • Insufficiently restricted endpoint access

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data due to unauthorized network access
  • Integrity: Data manipulation or tampering through unsecured network channels
  • Availability: Service disruptions from unauthorized network traffic or denial of service attacks
  • Reputation: Organizational damage due to data breaches and security incidents

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Publicly Accessible Endpoints: A SageMaker endpoint is configured without VPC isolation and is accessible from the internet. An attacker discovers the endpoint and exploits vulnerabilities to access sensitive data and models.
  • Misconfigured Security Groups: Training jobs are launched without proper security group restrictions, allowing unauthorized network access from other instances within the VPC or even from the internet.
  • Lack of Network Isolation: SageMaker notebook instances are deployed without VPC configurations, exposing them to public networks. An attacker intercepts the network traffic and exfiltrates sensitive information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1021 - Remote Services||ATLAS - AML.T0049 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Unencrypted inter-container communication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unencrypted inter-container communication refers to the transmission of data between containers in a SageMaker environment without encryption. This can expose sensitive information to interception and unauthorized access, especially in distributed training scenarios where data is frequently exchanged between multiple containers.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • External attackers (hackers)
    • Malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Network eavesdropping on inter-container traffic
    • Exploitation of network vulnerabilities to intercept data
    • Lack of encryption mechanisms in the container communication setup

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data such as model parameters, training data, and other proprietary information
  • Integrity: Risk of data tampering during transmission, leading to corrupted models or inaccurate results
  • Compliance: Non-compliance with data protection regulations requiring encryption of sensitive data in transit
  • Reputation: Damage to organizational trust and reputation due to data breaches

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Network Eavesdropping: An attacker gains access to the network segment where SageMaker containers are communicating. Without encryption, the attacker can intercept and read sensitive data being transmitted between containers.
  • Man-in-the-Middle Attack: An attacker inserts themselves between communicating containers in a distributed training job, intercepting and potentially altering the data being exchanged. This compromises the integrity of the training process and the resulting model.
  • Internal Threat: A malicious insider with network access to the SageMaker environment can capture unencrypted traffic between containers, gaining access to sensitive information and potentially leaking it.

countermeasure.name: Configure broker logs delivery to CloudWatch, S3, or Firehose
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security monitoring of your AWS Managed Streaming for Apache Kafka (MSK) cluster, configure your MSK cluster to deliver INFO-level broker logs to destinations such as Amazon CloudWatch Logs, Amazon S3, or Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose. Implementing this countermeasure involves the following steps:

  1. Enable Broker Logging: Ensure that broker logging is enabled on your MSK cluster. You can specify the log delivery options when you create the cluster or update the configuration of an existing cluster. Refer to the MSK logging documentation for detailed instructions.
  2. Choose Log Destination: Decide where you want the logs to be delivered:
    • Amazon CloudWatch Logs: Select this option for real-time monitoring and alerting capabilities. Configure the log group and define IAM roles and policies for log delivery. For more information, refer to CloudWatch Logs setup guide.
    • Amazon S3: Use S3 to store logs for long-term retention and analysis. Specify the S3 bucket and implement the required IAM policies. Refer to S3 logs setup guide.
    • Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose: Choose Firehose for streamlining log processing and delivery to various destinations. Set up the Firehose delivery stream and apply the necessary IAM policies. See the Firehose setup guide for further details.
  3. Secure IAM Roles and Policies: Ensure that the IAM roles and policies associated with log delivery have the least privilege necessary to perform their functions. Refer to the IAM Security guidelines in the MSK documentation for best practices.
  4. Verify Log Delivery: After configuring log delivery, validate that logs are being correctly sent to the chosen destination. Check the log streams in CloudWatch, the objects in your S3 bucket, or the records in Kinesis Firehose to ensure logs are comprehensive and correctly timestamped.
  5. Monitor and Analyze Logs: Regularly monitor and analyze the INFO-level broker logs to detect any unusual or unauthorized activities. Use AWS security tools like Amazon GuardDuty and AWS Security Hub for advanced threat detection and correlation of log data. Detailed steps can be found in the Monitoring Guide.

For comprehensive security guidelines, please refer to the AWS MSK Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Update security group rules to restrict access
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that your clients have access to the brokers in your AWS MSK cluster, you need to properly configure the security group's rules associated with your MSK cluster. This involves setting inbound and outbound rules that allow traffic between your clients and the brokers while maintaining adherence to AWS security best practices. Below is a step-by-step guide:

  1. Identify the Security Group: First, identify the security group currently associated with your MSK cluster. You can find this information in the AWS Management Console by navigating to the Amazon MSK console.

  2. Access the Security Group Settings: In the MSK console, go to the Cluster details page and then to the Network section. Note the IDs of the security groups used by the brokers.

  3. Edit Inbound Rules: Navigate to the Amazon EC2 console, and then to the Security Groups section. Locate the security groups identified in the previous step, and edit their inbound rules to allow necessary traffic from your clients. Ensure you add rules for the appropriate ports used by MSK (default is TCP port 9092).

    • Click on the Inbound rules tab.
    • Click on the Edit inbound rules button.
    • Add a new rule to allow traffic from your client IP ranges. Specify the Protocol (TCP), Port Range (9092), and the appropriate Source (your clients IP or Security Group ID).
    • Click on the Save rules button to apply the changes.

  4. Edit Outbound Rules: Ensure the outbound rules permit traffic to the client IPs. Similar to inbound rules, edit the outbound rules for the security group to allow traffic to specified IP ranges and ports.

    • Click on the Outbound rules tab.
    • Click on the Edit outbound rules button.
    • Add a new rule to allow traffic to your client IP ranges. Specify the Protocol (TCP), Port Range (9092 or other custom ports), and the appropriate Destination (your clients IP or Security Group ID).
    • Click on the Save rules button to apply the changes.

  5. Verify the Configuration: After configuring the security group's rules, ensure that your clients can connect to the brokers without issues. Test the connectivity and ensure that the proper permissions are in place.

  6. Review and Maintain: Regularly review and update the security group rules to align with changing security requirements and best practices. Reference the AWS Managed Streaming for Apache Kafka security documentation for any updates or additional guidelines: AWS MSK Security Documentation.

Following these steps ensures that your AWS MSK cluster remains accessible to legitimate clients while adhering to security best practices as outlined in the AWS documentation. For more detailed guidelines, please refer to the AWS official documentation on changing security groups: Change Security Group for AWS MSK.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM to authenticate clients for Apache Kafka APIs
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon MSK allows you to leverage AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) to authenticate clients and control Apache Kafka actions. This enables secure and fine-grained access control mechanisms. To implement this, follow these guidelines:

  1. Set Up IAM Policies: Create IAM policies that specify the Kafka actions permitted for your users or applications. Refer to IAM Access Control for Amazon MSK for detailed instructions on crafting policies.
  2. Attach Policies to Users or Roles: Assign the newly created IAM policies to users or roles that need access to your MSK clusters. This can be done via the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs.
  3. Configure Client Authentication: Update your Apache Kafka clients to use IAM for authentication. The AWS SDK provides mechanisms for this, including automatic signing of requests with IAM credentials. Details can be found in the section Client Authentication with IAM.
  4. Update Cluster Configurations: Modify the MSK cluster configurations to enable IAM authentication. This can be managed through the AWS Management Console or the AWS CLI. More information is available in the MSK Cluster Configuration documentation.
  5. Regularly Review and Audit IAM Policies: Review and audit your IAM policies and roles periodically to ensure that only the necessary permissions are granted. This ensures adherence to the principle of least privilege, reducing potential security vulnerabilities.

By following these steps and best practices, you can leverage IAM to securely authenticate clients and manage access to Kafka actions within your MSK clusters.

For further information on securing your Amazon MSK clusters, visit the Official Amazon MSK Security Documentation.
